[[Socialism]] |crimes= |attacks= |status= |size= |revenue= |financing= }} The '''al-Aqsa Martyrs' Brigades''' ({{lang-ar|كتائب شهداء الأقصى}} ''Katā'ib Shuhadā' al-'Aqṣā'') is a secular [[coalition]] of [[Palestinians|Palestinian]] armed groups in the [[West Bank]]. The organization has been designated as a [[terrorist organization]] by Israel, the [[European Union]],[http://eur-lex.europa.eu/LexUriServ/site/en/oj/2005/l_340/l_34020051223en00640066.pdf], [[Official Journal of the European Union]], 30 September 2005{{cite book|last=Kushner|first=Harvey|title=Encyclopedia of Terrorism|publisher=Sage Publications Inc|year=2002|page=11|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=ZOfkAoDb_2IC&pg=PA11&dq=Al-Aqsa+Brigades&lr=&sig=gaorV2LoWmqz5Di4u7yIDZ0S5t4}} [[Canada]],[http://www.psepc.gc.ca/prg/ns/le/cle-en.asp#aamb5 "Currently listed entities"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20061119150657/http://www.psepc.gc.ca/prg/ns/le/cle-en.asp |date=19 November 2006 }}, [[Public Safety and Emergency Preparedness Canada]], 11 November 2006 [[Japan]][http://www.mofa.go.jp/policy/other/bluebook/2005/ch3-a.pdf Japan‘s Foreign Policy in Major Diplomatic Fields] [[New Zealand]],{{cite web |url=http://www.police.govt.nz/advice/personal-community/counterterrorism/designated-entities/lists-associated-with-resolution-1373 |title=Lists associated with Resolution 1373 |publisher=New Zealand Police |date=20 July 2014 |accessdate=16 August 2014}} and the [[United States]].[https://www.state.gov/s/ct/rls/fs/37191.htm "Foreign Terrorist Organizations (FTOs)"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20071212050031/https://www.state.gov/s/ct/rls/fs/37191.htm |date=12 December 2007 }}, [[United States Department of State|U.S. Department of State]], 11 October 2005 ==Arafat and Fatah== The leadership of the brigades, and average members have identified themselves as the military wing of [[Fatah]]. On their website, and on posters, they post the Fatah emblem. The leadership of Fatah has said they never made a decision either to create the brigades, or make them the militant wing of Fatah. Since 2002, some leaders in Fatah have reportedly tried to get the brigades to stop attacking civilians.{{cite book|last=Stork|first=Joe|authorlink=Joe Stork|title=Erased in a Moment: Suicide Bombing Attacks Against Israeli Civilians|publisher=Human Rights Watch|year=2002|page=78|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=CGiot772MSEC&pg=PA77&dq=Al-Aqsa+Martyrs%27+Brigades&sig=tZif7ASqqEZYer5I5Q_ubsrjSO0#PPA78,M1}} In November 2003, BBC journalists uncovered a payment by Fatah of $50,000 a month to al-Aqsa.{{cite news| url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/world/middle_east/3243071.stm|newspaper=BBC News|title=Palestinian Authority funds go to militants|date=7 November 2003|accessdate=23 April 2010}} This investigation, combined with the documents found by the [[Israel Defense Forces]] (IDF), led the [[government of Israel]] to draw the conclusion that the al-Aqsa Martyrs' Brigades have always been directly funded by [[Yasser Arafat]]. In June 2004, then [[Prime Minister of the Palestinian National Authority|Palestinian Prime Minister]] [[Ahmed Qurei]] openly stated this: "We have clearly declared that the Aksa Martyrs' Brigades are part of Fatah. We are committed to them and Fatah bears full responsibility for the group."{{cite web|url=http://www.eufunding.org/accountability/AbuToameh_Fatah_AksaMartyrs.html |title=Fatah committed to Aksa Martyrs |publisher=EU Funding |date=20 April 2004 |accessdate=17 November 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120716211126/http://www.eufunding.org/accountability/AbuToameh_Fatah_AksaMartyrs.html |archivedate=16 July 2012 }} In July, he further declared "The al-Aqsa Martyrs Brigades, military wing of the Fatah movement will not be dissolved and Fatah will never relinquish its military wing."[http://www.imra.org.il/story.php3?id=21474 IMRA 24 July 2004 PMW: Arafat Blames Israel for Tel Aviv Bombing]{{Unreliable source?|reason=Website does not provide link to source for quote, seems like a propaganda website.|date=October 2015}} On 18 December 2003, Fatah asked the leaders of the al-Aqsa Martyr's Brigades to join the Fatah Council, recognizing it officially as part of the Fatah organization.[https://fas.org/sgp/crs/mideast/RS21235.pdf Palestinian Factions, CRS Report for Congress, Aaron D. Pina, 8 June 2005] ==Activities== [[File:Al-aqsa aamb.gif|thumb|200px|Flag of the al-Aqsa Martyrs' Brigades]] The al-Aqsa brigades are responsible for dozens of [[suicide bombing]]s and many more shooting attacks against Israeli vehicles in the [[West Bank]]. For a complete list of the suicide bombings carried out by the organization see: [[List of Palestinian suicide attacks]]. Some notable suicide bombings committed by the group were: *January 2002: [[Bat Mitzvah massacre]], when a gunman killed six and wounded 33 in a [[Bat Mitzvah]] celebration.{{cite news|last=Reeves|first=Phil|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/middle-east/bat--mitzvah-massacre-in-israel-leaves-seven-dead-663843.html|title=Bat mitzvah massacre in Israel leaves seven dead|newspaper=The Independent|date=18 January 2002|accessdate=17 November 2012}} *19 February 2002: an attack on an IDF [[Ein 'Arik checkpoint attack|checkpoint at Ein 'Arik]], near [[Ramallah]], where one officer and five soldiers were killed. *3 March 2002: an attack by a single sniper on an IDF checkpoint at [[Wadi al-Haramiya sniper attack|Wadi al-Haramiya]], near [[Ofra]], where 2 officers and five soldiers were killed and five soldiers wounded. Three civilian settlers were also killed in the incident. *2 March 2002: Beit Yisrael, [[Jerusalem]] – 11 killed.{{cite news| url=http://premium.edition.cnn.com/2002/WORLD/meast/03/02/jerusalem.bomb/|newspaper=CNN|title=Jerusalem bombing kills 9 bystanders|date=2 March 2002|accessdate=23 April 2010}} *5 January 2003: Southern Tel Aviv central bus station – 22 killed. *29 January 2004: Rehavia, Jerusalem, bus line 19 – 11 killed. *14 March 2004: Port of [[Ashdod]] – 10 killed (together with [[Hamas]]). On 16 October 2005, the al-Aqsa Martyrs' Brigades claimed responsibility for a shooting attack at the [[Gush Etzion]] Junction, killing three Israelis and wounding three others. On 24 March 2004, a Palestinian teenager named [[Hussam Abdo]] was caught in an [[Israeli Defense Forces|IDF]] checkpoint carrying an [[explosive belt]]. Following his arrest, an al-Aqsa Martyrs' Brigade teenagers' militant cell was exposed and arrested in [[Nablus]].{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2004/05/30/international/middleeast/30teen.html |newspaper=The New York Times |title=Israel Says Children Are Used to Recruit Bombers |first=Greg |last=Myre |date=30 May 2004 |accessdate=27 March 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090802024301/http://www.nytimes.com/2004/05/30/international/middleeast/30teen.html |archivedate=2 August 2009 }} On 23 September 2004, a 15-year-old suicide bomber was arrested by [[Israeli security forces]].{{cite paper|last=Harel|first=Amos|url=http://www.haaretz.com/hasen/spages/481217.html|title=Heightened alert set for Yom Kippur; Afula attack thwarted|newspaper=Haaretz|date=23 September 2004|accessdate=17 November 2012}} {{Main|Child suicide bomber}} The Brigades, like many militia groups, is noted for the use of promotional posters in the main cities of the Palestinian territories. The Brigades have attacked Palestinians as well as Israelis. In November and December 2003, they killed the brother of [[Ghassan Shakaa]] (the mayor of [[Nablus]]).{{cite news|url=http://weekly.ahram.org.eg/2004/709/re3.htm |title=Not another day in Nablus |newspaper=Weekly Ahram |date=29 September 2004 |accessdate=17 November 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120716190016/http://weekly.ahram.org.eg/2004/709/re3.htm |archivedate=16 July 2012 |df= }} In February 2004 Shakaa filed his resignation from office in protest of the [[Palestinian Authority]]'s lack of action against the armed militias "rampaging" the city.{{cite news|url=http://www.abc.net.au/am/content/2004/s1056078.htm |title=AM Archive - Nablus Mayor resigns over lawlessness|newspaper=Abc|year=2004|accessdate=17 November 2012}}{{cite web|author=Middle East Information Center |url=http://middleeastinfo.org/article.php?sid=3978 |title=Conflicts, News, History, Religions and Discussions |publisher=Middleeast Info |accessdate=17 November 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120716211201/http://middleeastinfo.org/article.php?sid=3978 |archivedate=16 July 2012 |df= }} During the first three months of 2004, a number of attacks on journalists in the West Bank and Gaza Strip were blamed on the Brigades as well, including the attack on the Arab television station [[Al Arabiya]]'s West Bank offices by masked men who identified themselves as members of the Brigades. Palestinian journalists in Gaza called a general strike on 0 February 2004 to protest this rising violence against journalists. The al-Aqsa Martyrs' Brigades have taken prominent part in the July 2004 riots in the Gaza Strip, in which Palestinian officers were kidnapped and PA security headquarters buildings and policemen were attacked by gunmen.{{cite web|url=http://www.bicom.org.uk/publications/israeli-palestinian_conflict/?content_id=721 |title=Increased pressure on Arafat to reform PA or resign |accessdate=12 November 2005 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20060525230611/http://www.bicom.org.uk/publications/israeli-palestinian_conflict/?content_id=721 |archivedate=25 May 2006 }} These riots led the Palestinian cabinet to declare a state of emergency. One media outlet described the situation in the [[Palestinian Authority]] as [[Anomie|anarchy]] and [[Chaos (cosmogony)|chaos]]. The al-Aqsa Martyrs' Brigades have carried out several joint attacks with the Islamist group [[Hamas]]. These attacks were committed mainly in the [[Gaza Strip]]. ''See also:'' [[PLO and Hamas]]. The al-Aqsa Martyrs' Brigades have also carried out joint attack with other militant groups such as [[Palestinian Islamic Jihad]], [[The Popular Resistance Committees]] and with [[Hezbollah]] in the [[West Bank]]. The [[European Union]]'s [[Gaza City|Gaza]] offices were raided by 15 masked gunmen from al-Aqsa Martyrs' Brigades on 30 January 2006. They demanded apologies from Denmark and Norway regarding the [[Jyllands-Posten Muhammad cartoons]] and left 30 minutes later without shots fired or injuries.{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/world/middle_east/4661572.stm|newspaper=BBC|title=Gaza EU offices raided by gunmen|date=30 January 2006|accessdate=27 March 2010}} On 9 June 2007, in a failed assault on an IDF position at the Kissufim crossing between Gaza and Israel in a possible attempt to kidnap IDF soldiers, 4 armed members of the [[al-Quds Brigades]] - the military wing of Islamic Jihad - and the Al-Aqsa Martyrs' Brigades - the military wing of [[Fatah]] -, used a vehicle marked with "TV" and "PRESS" insignias penetrated the border fence and assaulted a guard tower in what Islamic Jihad and the army said was a failed attempt to capture an Israeli soldier.[http://fr.jpost.com/servlet/Satellite?cid=1181228588087&pagename=JPost/JPArticle/ShowFull Press slams gunmen for using TV jeep|Jerusalem Post]{{dead link|date=June 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} IDF troops killed one militant, while the others escaped. The use of a vehicle that resembled a press vehicle evoked a sharp response from many journalists and news organizations, including the Foreign Press Association and [[Human Rights Watch]].[http://hrw.org/english/docs/2007/06/13/isrlpa16156.htm Gaza: Armed Palestinian Groups Commit Grave Crimes (Human Rights Watch, 13 June 2007)] On 14 July 2007, [[Zakaria Zubeidi]], considered the local al-Aqsa leader for [[Jenin]] and the northern West Bank and has been wanted for many years for his armed activity against Israel, agreed to cease fighting against Israel{{fr icon}}[http://www.rfi.fr/actufr/articles/091/article_54084.asp Un chef de guerre dépose les armes] (translation: "A war chief lays down his arms") after Prime Minister Ehud Olmert gave conditional pardon for 178 prisoners from the PA territories. ==Amnesty deal== In July, 2007, Israel and the Palestinian Authority reached an amnesty deal under which 178 al-Aqsa gunmen surrendered their arms to the Palestinian Authority, renounced future anti-Israel violence and were permitted to join Palestinian security forces.{{cite news|last=Greenberg|first=Joel|url=http://articles.chicagotribune.com/2007-07-16/news/0707150274_1_al-aqsa-martyrs-brigades-hamas-west-bank|title=Militants Accept Amnesty|publisher=Chicago Tribune|date=16 July 2007|accessdate=5 May 2011}} Later agreements in 2007 and 2008 added more gunmen to the list of those granted amnesty in exchange for ending violence, eventually bringing the total to over 300.{{cite news|url=http://www.ynetnews.com/articles/0,7340,L-3433924,00.html |title=Report: Some 300 Gunmen Accept Israel's Amnesty Deal|newspaper=Ynet|date=7 May 2008|accessdate=5 May 2011}} On 22 August 2007, according to [[Arutz Sheva]], al-Aqsa Martyrs' Brigade announced that it was backing out of its commitment and promise to refrain from attacks against Israel and the Israeli backed amnesty deal giving amnesty to 178 al-Aqsa gunmen who agreed to stop militant activities against Israel and surrender their weapons.[http://www.israelnationalnews.com/News/News.aspx/123470 Fatah Claims Shooting Attack, Terrorists Break Amnesty Deal - Defense/Middle East - Israel News - Arutz Sheva] al-Aqsa said that it backed out of the deal due to the IDF's arrest of two militants who were supposed to be on the amnesty list. According to the IDF, they said they caught the two men at a checkpoint and said they were involved in "terrorist activity" which consequently mandated their arrest according to the stipulations of the amnesty deal. Shortly after backing out of the amnesty deal and its promise of stopping to attack Israel that Al Aqsa agreed to a month earlier, al-Aqsa gunmen in Gaza have announced that they are starting to launch hundreds of rockets and mortar shells at Israeli towns and cities and named the campaign, "Hole in the Wall II." ==Members== Notable members of the al-Aqsa Martyrs' Brigade (ordered lexicographically according to the last name) includes active militants and militants that were killed or arrested by the [[Israeli security forces]]. *[[Naif Abu-Sharah]] : local commander in [[Nablus]] (killed by [[Israel Defense Forces|IDF]]). *[[Fadi Kafisha]]: former head of the Tanzim in Nablus; killed by IDF in 2006. *[[Sirhan Sirhan (militant)|Sirhan Sirhan]]: (Not to be confused with the [[Sirhan Sirhan]] responsible for killing [[Robert Kennedy]].) Responsible for killing 5 people, including a mother and her 2 children in the [[2002 Kibbutz Metzer terrorist attack]]. Killed by [[Yamam]] in 2003. *[[Zakaria Zubeidi]]: local commander in [[Jenin]], known for his relationship with Israeli [[far left]] activist [[Tali Fahima]]. *[[Samih Madhoun]], senior leader. Killed in 2007 by the [[Izz ad-Din al-Qassam Brigades|al-Qassam Brigades]] ==Popular culture== In the [[Sacha Baron Cohen]] movie ''[[Brüno]]'', the character Brüno interviewed [[Palestinian Christian]] Ayman Abu Aita, who was portrayed in the movie as a leader of the militant group. The group released a statement to a Jerusalem-based journalist saying that it was "very upset" that it had been featured in the film.{{cite news|author1=Brown, David |author2=Kartik, Mehta|date=28 July 2009|title=Terrorist threat to Sacha Baron Cohen over Brüno ridicule|newspaper=The Sunday Times|url=http://entertainment.timesonline.co.uk/tol/arts_and_entertainment/film/article6729022.ece|accessdate=9 May 2011}} Abu Aita insists that he was tricked into appearing in the film and that he has never been involved with the Martyrs' Brigades. In an interview with ''[[Time (magazine)|Time]]'', Abu Aita stated, "It is true that I was jailed in 2003...I was active in resisting the occupation, in non-violent ways."{{cite news|date=28 July 2009|title=Brüno's 'Terrorist' Speaks Out|newspaper=Time Magazine|url=http://www.time.com/time/video/?bcpid=1485842900&bctid=30636435001|accessdate=9 May 2011}} After a clip of the interview was played on the ''[[Late Show with David Letterman]]'', Ayman called Baron Cohen a "big liar".{{Citation needed|date=January 2012}} Abu Aita subsequently filed a $110 million lawsuit against Baron Cohen and [[David Letterman]].{{cite news|author =Zongker, Brett|date=9 December 2009|title=Ayman Abu Aita Sues 'Bruno,' Letterman for $110M|newspaper=Huffington Post|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2009/12/09/ayman-abu-aita-sues-bruno_n_386294.html|accessdate=11 February 2017|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160316161125/http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2009/12/09/ayman-abu-aita-sues-bruno_n_386294.html|archivedate=16 March 2016}} The suit was settled before trial.{{cite news|title=Sascha Baron Cohen settles lawsuit by grocer he called a 'terrorist' in movie Bruno|url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-2176647/Sascha-Baron-Cohen-settles-lawsuit-grocer-called-terrorist.html|accessdate=11 February 2017|publisher=[[The Daily Mail]]|date=20 July 2012}} ==See also== {{Wikipedia books |1=Islamic terrorism |3=Islamic terrorist groups }} * [[Fatah]] * [[Palestinian National Authority]] * [[Yasser Arafat]] * [[Popular Resistance Committees]] * [[Suicide attack|Suicide bombing]] * [[Child suicide bombers in the Israeli–Palestinian conflict]] * [[List of al-Aqsa Martyrs' Brigades suicide attacks]] * [[Palestinian domestic weapons production]] ==References== {{reflist|33em}} ==External links== *[http://www.3asfa.com/ar/index.php Al-Aqsa Martyrs Brigades website] (Arabic) *[https://web.archive.org/web/20080328061808/http://www.cfr.org/publication/9127/ Council on Foreign Relations. Terrorism Q&A: al-Aqsa Martyrs Brigades] *[http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/middle_east/1760492.stm Profile: al-Aqsa Martyrs' Brigade] *[http://www.ict.org.il/articles/articledet.cfm?articleid=430 The al-Aqsa Martyrs Brigades: A political tool with an edge], from Israel's Institute for Counter-Terrorism. *[http://www.nfc.co.il/archive/001-D-36483-00.html?tag=12-37-46 al-Aqsa Martyrs' Brigades Joins the Fatah Council.] *[http://memri.org/bin/articles.cgi?Page=archives&Area=sd&ID=SP67504 Daily Life in the Palestininian Authority] *[http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/world/middle_east/3243071.stm BBC: Palestinian Authority Funds go to Militants] {{Israeli-Palestinian Conflict}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Aqsa Martyrs' Brigades}} [[Category:Anti-Zionism in the Palestinian territories]] [[Category:Socialism in the Palestinian territories]] [[Category:Fatah]] [[Category:Paramilitary organizations based in the State of Palestine]] [[Category:Palestinian militant groups]] [[Category:Military wings of political parties]] [[Category:Palestinian terrorism]] [[Category:Resistance movements]] [[Category:Organizations designated as terrorist by Canada]] [[Category:Organisations designated as terrorist by the European Union]] [[Category:Organizations designated as terrorist by Israel]] [[Category:Organisations designated as terrorist by Japan]] [[Category:Organisations designated as terrorist by New Zealand]] [[Category:Organisations designated as terrorist by the United Kingdom]] [[Category:Organizations designated as terrorist by the United States]] [[Category:Organizations designated as terrorist in Asia]] [[Category:Palestinian nationalism]]

bar|5|150|hex=#8B0000}} | colours = {{Color box|#AE0010|border=darkgray}} {{Color box|#E8B12D|border=darkgray}} [[Red]], [[Gold (color)|Gold]] }} The '''Alliance of Patriots of Georgia''' ({{lang-ka|საქართველოს პატრიოტთა ალიანსი}}, ''Sakartvelos Patriotta Aliansi'', APG) is a self-defined [[Centre-right politics|centre-right]], [[pro-Russian]], [[Conservatism|conservative]] opposition party in the republic of [[Georgia (country)|Georgia]].{{cite journal|url=https://foreignpolicy.com/2015/03/09/the-kremlin-pulls-on-georgia/ |title=The Kremlin pulls on Georgia |first=Michael |last=Cecire |date=March 9, 2015 |journal=[[Foreign Policy (magazine)|Foreign Policy]]}} It was founded in 2012 by leaders from the Resistance Movement and its platform includes anti-Western positions.{{cite journal|url=https://www.foreignaffairs.com/articles/georgia/2015-11-10/divide-and-conquer-georgia |title=Divide and conquer in Georgia |first=Michael |last=Cecire |date=November 10, 2015 |journal=[[Foreign Affairs (magazine)|Foreign Affairs]]}} The party currently supports [[European integration]], it supports Christian and democratic values, and the party demonstrates itself as a [[Liberal conservatism|moderate-conservative]] party.{{cite website|url=http://patriots.ge/about-temp/ |title=Alliance of Patriots of Georgia |first= |last= |date= |journal=[[Political Party’s Page]]}} The party campaigned against the building of a mosque in [[Adjara]], saying “Turkey has too much influence in Georgia,” so it has been accused of [[Anti-Turkism]].{{cite website|url=https://eurasianet.org/s/georgia-disillusion-with-establishment-fuels-rise-of-populism |title=Georgia: Disillusion with Establishment Fuels Rise of Populism |first=Joshua |last=Kucera |date= Oct 24, 2016|journal=[[Eurasianet]]}} The party favours closer ties with both Russia and the European Union.{{cite website|url=https://eurasianet.org/s/georgia-disillusion-with-establishment-fuels-rise-of-populism |title=Georgia: Disillusion with Establishment Fuels Rise of Populism |first=Joshua |last=Kucera |date= Oct 24, 2016|journal=[[Eurasianet]]}} In the 2014 local elections, it gained an aggregate vote nationwide of 4.6%, exceeding the 4% threshold required to qualify as a political party for government funding. Through party-list voting in 47 cities, it won proportional seat representation on the local councils of 30 municipalities, including [[Tbilisi]]. In June 2016, the party formed a bloc with five other parties (Free Georgia, led by [[Kakha Kukava]]; [[Tavisupleba (political party)|Tavisupleba]], led by [[Konstantine Gamsakhurdia (politician)|Konstantine Gamsakhurdia]]; Traditionalists, led by [[Akaki Asatiani]]; [[Christian-Democratic Movement (Georgia)|New Christian-Democrats]], led by [[Gocha Jojua]], and Political Movement of Law Enforcement and Armed Forces Veterans) for the scheduled 2016 parliamentary election,{{cite news|last1=|first1=|title=Alliance of Patriots Forms 6-Party Bloc for Elections|url=http://civil.ge/eng/article.php?id=29218|accessdate=29 July 2016|work=Civil Georgia|date=9 June 2016}} finishing 3rd place in the proportional votе and just passing the [[electoral threshold]] of 5%. ==History== The party was established in December 2012,[http://www.rferl.org/content/georgia-electoral-reform-concerns/27437225.html Georgian Electoral Amendment Clears Early Hurdle, But Vote Concerns Persist] Radio Free Europe/Radio Liberty, 19 December 2015 by founders including [[Soso Manjavidze]], [[Davit Tarkhan-Mouravi]] and [[Irma Inashvili]]. Giorgi Lomia is political secretary. The party leadership also includes former warlord [[Emzar Kvitsiani]], a figure that has attracted significant controversy.{{cite news|last1=Fuller|first1=Liz|title=Georgian Court Releases Jailed Warlord|url=http://www.rferl.org/a/georgia-kvitsiani-russia/26818432.html|accessdate=23 October 2016|agency=Radio Free Europe|date=January 28, 2015}} The Alliance party was based on the Resistance Movement, a group fiercely critical of the former ruling party, the [[United National Movement (Georgia)|United National Movement]]. The Alliance of Patriots maintains anti-Turkish rhetoric, warning of Ankara's designs on the Adjara region, has called for delaying free trade with the EU, and argues that the pursuit of NATO membership is fruitless, as NATO's leading members have themselves made clear that Georgia has little prospect of accession. The Alliance party has a television channel, Obieqtivi, run by Inashvili. Davit Tarkhan-Mouravi has a series on the channel in which he lectures on the Bible and [[Orthodox Christianity]]. A mathematician, he served in earlier administrations as "head of the state department for information technologies in the early 2000s, and as head of the customs department for several months in 2003." In the [[Georgian local elections, 2014|2014 local elections]], the [[Georgian Dream]] coalition, including the Republican Party, gained 50.80%; they have been leading the government since 2012. The UNM gained a nationwide party-list vote in 2014 of 22.41%. [[Nino Burjanadze]] and her [[Democratic Movement – United Georgia|United Opposition]] coalition gained the third best results in the local elections, with nationwide 10.22% in the party-list vote. Burjanadze revived a Eurasianist rhetoric, which is supported by Russia, and the campaign was "fueled by massive influxes of what was likely Russian money." The Alliance of Patriots of Georgia party received 4.7% of the aggregate vote, meeting the required threshold of 4% to qualify as a political party, and making it eligible for future state funding for elections. It ran in a party-list contest for proportional Sakrebulo seats in 47 of a total of 71 municipalities and cities. In 30 jurisdictions, its party-list voting exceeded 4%, making it eligible for seats on 30 local councils, including that of [[Tbilisi]].[http://www.civil.ge/eng/article.php?id=27395 "Local Elections Boost Alliance of Patriots’ Ambitions for Parliamentary Polls"], ''Civil Georgia,'' 21 June 2014Tom Lansford (2015) ''Political Handbook of the World 2015'', CQ Press Inashvili finished fourth in the mayoral election in [[Tbilisi]] with 5.4% of the vote; the party won two seats in the [[Tbilisi City Assembly]]. In addition, Alliance of Patriots of Georgia mayoral candidates qualified for run-off elections against [[Georgian Dream]] (GD) candidates in the cities of [[Poti]] and [[Ozurgeti]]; and Alliance candidates qualified for second-round runoffs for municipal executives in the municipalities of [[Lanchkhuti]] and [[Khulo]]. ==Electoral performance== {| class="wikitable" style="text-align: right;" |- ! Election ! Leader ! Votes ! % ! Seats ! +/– ! Position ! Government |- ! {{Use British English|date=July 2015}} {{Infobox book | italic title = <!--(see above)--> | name = America Right or Wrong: An Anatomy of American Nationalism | image = File:America Right or Wrong.JPG | image_size = 200px | alt = | caption = | author = [[Anatol Lieven]] | audio_read_by = | country = United Kingdom | language = English | series = | release_number = | subject = [[Politics of the United States]] | set_in = | published = [[Oxford]], [[United Kingdom]] | publisher = [[Oxford University Press]] | publisher2 = | pub_date = 2012 | media_type = Print | pages = 296 | awards = | isbn = 9780199660254 | oclc = | dewey = 320.54097309051 | congress = | preceded_by = | followed_by = | native_wikisource = | wikisource = | notes = | exclude_cover = | website = }} '''''America Right or Wrong: An Anatomy of American Nationalism''''' is a 2012 book by the British author and academic [[Anatol Lieven]]. A separate, earlier version was published in 2004.
==Synopsis== The book investigates the [[far-right]] in American politics, the radicalisation of the [[Republican Party (US)|Republican Party]] and the [[Tea Party movement]]. The book also discusses the concept of [[American exceptionalism]].
==Reception== In ''[[Foreign Affairs]]'' the book was described as 'intelligent and often provocative'<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.foreignaffairs.com/reviews/capsule-review/2005-03-01/america-right-or-wrong-anatomy-american-nationalism|title=America Right or Wrong: An Anatomy of American Nationalism|work=Foreign Affairs}}</ref> whilst in ''[[The Guardian]]'' the book was praised by Martin Woollacott who wrote 'We should have seen it coming. All the signs were there in the 1990s - the mania about resisting outside influences, the narrow religious beliefs, the harking back to a golden age, the sense of being under threat from modernity, the readiness to use violent means. The roots of it went back centuries. But it took the attacks of 9/11 for us to realise how powerful was this burgeoning extremism....We are not, of course, talking here about Islam or about al-Qaida and Osama bin Laden, but about America. It is Anatol Lieven's contention in this illuminating book that Bin Laden's assault on the United States stripped away many of the remaining restraints on the intolerant, irrational, and self-destructive side of American nationalism. Whether this nationalism is a greater problem than that represented by Islamic extremism is a moot point, but it is clear that the combination of the two could bring disaster on us all'.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/books/2004/nov/13/highereducation.news1|title=Review: America, Right or Wrong by Anatol Lieven|author=Martin Woollacott|work=the Guardian}}</ref> In the ''[[London Review of Books]]'' the work was praised as 'fascinating and incisive...a compelling argument'.
