{{Infobox amusement park |name = Ark Encounter |image = Ark-encounter-2514667 960 720.jpg |caption = Noah's Ark at Ark Encounter (2016) |slogan = "It's bigger than imagination"<ref name=wow>{{cite news |last = Meehan |first= Mary |date = June 26, 2016 |title = Massive ark attraction set to open in Northern Kentucky |url = https://www.kentucky.com/living/article86106097.html |work = [[Lexington Herald-Leader]] |location = [[Lexington, Kentucky]] |publisher = [[The McClatchy Company]] |access-date = April 29, 2017}}</ref> |location = [[Grant County, Kentucky|Grant County]] |location2 = [[Kentucky]] |location3 = United States |coordinates = {{Coord|38.622240|-84.592282|type:landmark||display=inline,title}} |theme = [[Noah's Ark]] |owner = Ark Encounter, LLC |operator = [[Answers in Genesis]] |opening_date = {{Start date|2016|07|07}} |season = Year-round |visitors = 862,471 - 1 million (July 2017–June 2018) |area = |homepage = [https://arkencounter.com arkencounter.com] |status = Open |footnotes = }}
'''Ark Encounter''' is a [[Creationism|creationist]] [[theme park]] that opened in [[Grant County, Kentucky|Grant County]], [[Kentucky]] on July 7, 2016.<ref name=WKYT>{{cite web|url=http://www.wkyt.com/content/news/Ark-park-teaches-Creationism-but-will-it-create-jobs-385829691.html|title=Visitors, protesters turn out for Ark Encounter opening in Grant County|first=Alain |last=Sherter|work=wkyt.com}}</ref><ref name = NYT160626 /> The centerpiece of the park is a large representation of [[Noah's Ark]] based on the [[Genesis flood narrative]] contained in the [[Bible]]. It is {{convert|510|ft|m|0}} long, {{convert|85|ft|m}} wide, and {{convert|51|ft|m}} high.
Ark Encounter is operated by [[Answers in Genesis]] (AiG), a [[young Earth creationist]] (YEC) organization that also operates the [[Creation Museum]] {{convert|45|mi|km|-1}} away in [[Petersburg, Boone County, Kentucky|Petersburg, Kentucky]].<ref name=WKYT/> The theme park promotes [[pseudoscientific]] [[young Earth creationism|young Earth creationist]] beliefs about the [[age of the universe]], [[age of the Earth]], and co-existence of man and non-avian [[dinosaur]]s.<ref name = NYT160626>{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2016/06/26/us/noahs-ark-creationism-ken-ham.html|title=A Noah’s Ark in Kentucky, Dinosaurs Included|last=Goodstein|first=Laurie|date=2016-06-26|work=The New York Times|access-date=2017-04-29|issn=0362-4331}}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal|date=2016-08-13|title=That sinking feeling|url=https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0262407916314567|journal=New Scientist|language=en|volume=231|issue=3086|pages=18–19|doi=10.1016/S0262-4079(16)31456-7|issn=0262-4079}}</ref><ref name=Ortiz>{{Cite news |last = Ortiz |first = Erik |date = July 16, 2016 |url=http://www.nbcnews.com/science/science-news/absolutely-wrong-bill-nye-science-guy-takes-noah-s-ark-n608721 |title='Absolutely Wrong': Bill Nye Takes on Noah's Ark Exhibit |work=NBC News |access-date=2017-04-29 |language=en}}</ref><ref>{{Cite book|url=https://www.worldcat.org/oclc/952421434|title=Lost city, found pyramid : understanding alternative archaeologies and pseudoscientific practices|others=Card, Jeb J.,, Anderson, David S., 1978-|isbn=9780817319113|location=Tuscaloosa|oclc=952421434|page=86}}</ref>
After feasibility studies projected that the park would be a boon to the state's tourism industry, the Ark Encounter received tax incentives from the city, county, and state to induce its construction. This drew criticism from groups concerned with the [[separation of church and state]].<ref name=loftus>{{cite web | last1=Loftus | first1=Tom | title=Ark Park Tax Incentives Worth Up to $18M Approved | url=http://www.courier-journal.com/story/news/politics/ky-governor/2016/04/26/ark-park-tax-incentives-worth-up-18m-approved/83540204/ | date=April 26, 2016 | work=[[Courier-Journal]] | accessdate=April 27, 2016}}</ref> A dispute over AiG's hiring practices was adjudicated in U.S. federal court, which found in 2016 that the organization could require Ark Encounter employees to sign a statement of faith as a condition of their employment, prompting criticism of the park's discriminatory hiring practices.<ref name=WKYT/>
==Visitor experience== [[File:AE scutosaurus.jpg|thumb|right|A model of a ''[[Scutosaurus]]'' displayed inside Ark Encounter is identified as a representative of the [[Pareiasaur|pareiasaur]] "[[baraminology|kind]]".]] The ark contains 132 bays, each standing about {{convert|18|ft|m}} high, arranged into three decks.<ref name=shape>{{cite news | last = Ward | first = Karla | date = June 26, 2016 | title = Noah’s Ark takes shape in Grant County | url = http://www.kentucky.com/news/local/counties/fayette-county/article61547932.html | work = [[Lexington Herald-Leader]] | location = [[Lexington, Kentucky]] | publisher = [[The McClatchy Company]] | access-date = April 29, 2017 }}</ref><ref name=opens>{{cite web |last=Weed |first=Alexis |title=Noah's Ark opens at Kentucky theme park |publisher=CNN |date=July 7, 2016 |url=http://www.cnn.com/2016/07/07/us/noahs-ark-kentucky/ |accessdate=July 8, 2016}}</ref> Visitors enter on the lowest deck and move between decks on ramps constructed through the center of the ark.<ref name=massive>{{cite news |last=Blackford |first=Linda |date=July 7, 2016 |title=Massive Noah’s Ark park opens in Kentucky |url=http://www.kentucky.com/news/state/article88144982.html |work=[[Lexington Herald-Leader]] |publisher = [[The McClatchy Company]] |location = [[Lexington, Kentucky]] |access-date = April 29, 2017 }}</ref> Bays on the first deck contain models of some animals that AiG believes were on the ark; there are no live animals within the ark<ref name=wdrbopens>{{cite web |last=Sirianni |first=Maura |title=Ark Encounter opens in northern Kentucky |publisher=WDRB |date=July 7, 2016 |url=http://www.wdrb.com/story/32390935/ark-encounter-ready-for-opening-day-in-northern-kentucky |accessdate=July 8, 2016}}</ref><ref name=skepticism>{{cite web |last=Westerman |first=Ashley |title=Life-Size Noah's Ark To Open Amid A Flood Of Skepticism |publisher=National Public Radio |date=July 5, 2016 |url=https://www.npr.org/2016/07/05/484756640/life-size-noahs-ark-to-open-amid-a-flood-of-skepticism |accessdate=July 8, 2016}}</ref> though there is a petting zoo on the grounds.<ref name="WKYT" /><ref name="toknow">{{cite news|url=http://www.courier-journal.com/story/news/2016/07/07/what-know-if-youre-visiting-ark-encounter/86813400/|title=What to know if you're visiting Ark Encounter|last=Shapiro|first=Bobby|date=July 7, 2016|newspaper=The Courier-Journal|accessdate=July 8, 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite web | title=These Creationists Have a Bigger Plan than a Giant Ark | url=http://www.heraldonline.com/living/religion/article155643569.html | date=June 12, 2017 | publisher=''The Herald'' | accessdate=June 28, 2017}}</ref> The models are meant to represent "[[baraminology|kinds]]" of animals, which AiG says gave rise to modern animals after the flood.<ref name=creators>{{cite news |last=Gabbat |first=Adam |title=Creators of the lost ark: replica of Noah's vessel unveiled in Kentucky |newspaper=The Guardian |date=July 6, 2016 |url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2016/jul/06/noahs-ark-encounter-kentucky-replica-unveiled |accessdate=July 8, 2016}}</ref> Among the models presented, according to AiG co-founder Mark Looey prior to the Ark's opening, are [[dinosaurs]] and a pair of [[unicorns]].<ref name=skepticism />
The second deck contains more animal models, along with [[diorama]]s of Noah's workshop and a blacksmith.<ref name=wdrbopens /> Bays on the third deck contain displays presenting what AiG believes might have happened inside and outside the ark during the flood.<ref name=wdrbopens /> Displays in three of the bays include artifacts from the [[Green Collection]] and promote the [[Museum of the Bible]], a [[Washington, D.C.]] attraction constructed by the [[David Green (entrepreneur)|Green family]], who donated to the Ark Encounter's construction.<ref name=whopays /> [[RoadsideAmerica.com]] rated the displays depicting the sinful state of the world before the flood, including a priest sacrificing an infant to an unnamed snake god and people murdered in a gladiatorial event in an arena, as among the most memorable exhibits in the attraction.<ref name=rareview>{{cite web |title=Noah's Ark |publisher=RoadsideAmerica.com |url=https://www.roadsideamerica.com/story/53475 |date=January 1, 2018 |accessdate=January 2, 2018|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180105182733/https://www.roadsideamerica.com/story/53475|archivedate=January 5, 2018}}</ref>
The ark is held {{convert|15|ft|m}} off the ground by a series of concrete towers. The [[starboard]] side of the hull merges into three {{convert|80|ft|m|adj=on}} masonry towers containing stairwells, elevators, and restrooms.<ref name=shape />
==History== ===Planning=== On December 1, 2010, the [[young Earth creationism]] group [[Answers in Genesis]] (AiG) and the for-profit corporation Ark Encounter, LLC announced that they would partner to build a [[amusement park|theme park]] called Ark Encounter that, as they claimed, would "lend credence to the biblical account of a catastrophic flood and to dispel doubts that Noah could have fit two of every kind of animal onto a 500-foot-long ark".<ref name=arkannounce>{{cite news |last=Alford |first=Roger |title=Full-scale replica of Noah's Ark planned in Kentucky |agency=The Associated Press News Service |work=[[USA Today]] |date=December 3, 2010 |url=http://usatoday30.usatoday.com/travel/destinations/2010-12-05-noahs-ark-kentucky-creation-museum_N.htm |accessdate=April 20, 2016}}</ref> The partners projected that the fully completed park would cost $150 million, which they intended to raise privately.<ref name=wistv>{{cite web |title=Plans announced for 'Noah's Ark' attraction in NKY |publisher=WISTV |date=November 30, 2010 |url=http://www.wistv.com/story/13589609/religious-themed-amusement?clienttype=printable |accessdate=April 23, 2016}}</ref>
Under a program enacted by the [[Kentucky General Assembly]] in 2010, Ark Encounter investors applied for [[Economic Development Incentives|economic development incentives]] that would allow them to recoup 25 percent of the project's construction costs by keeping a portion of the park's [[sales tax]]es during its first ten years of operation.<ref name=defendtax>{{cite news |last=Hopkins |first=Shawntaye |date=December 2, 2010 |title=Beshear defends use of tax incentives |url=http://www.kentucky.com/news/politics-government/article44066556.html |work=[[Lexington Herald-Leader]] |publisher=[[The McClatchy Company]] |location = [[Lexington, Kentucky]] |access-date = April 29, 2017 }}</ref> Receipt of the incentives would be contingent upon Ark Encounter meeting established performance goals upon opening.<ref name=feasibility>{{cite news |last=Blackford |first=Linda B. |title=State cited feasibility study it hadn't seen on Ark park |newspaper=[[Lexington Herald-Leader]]|publisher=[[The McClatchy Company]] |location=[[Lexington, Kentucky]] |date=December 18, 2010 |url=http://www.kentucky.com/news/politics-government/article44070984.html |accessdate=April 23, 2010}}</ref> A press release from [[Governor of Kentucky|Kentucky Governor]] [[Steve Beshear]]'s office cited a feasibility study commissioned by Ark Encounter, LLC and conducted by consumer research corporation America's Research Group Limited, Inc.<ref name=feasibility /> The company had also conducted the feasibility study for AiG's Ark Encounter and an attitudinal survey included in Ken Ham's book ''Already Gone''; ARC founder C. Britt Beemer was credited as a co-author of the book.<ref name=feasibility/> This projected the park could employ 900 people, attract as many as 1.6 million visitors in its first year of operation, and generate a $214 million economic impact for the region.<ref name=arkannounce /><ref name="feasibility" /> The group selected an {{convert|800|acre|ha|adj=on}} parcel near [[Interstate 75]] in [[Grant County, Kentucky]], near the city of [[Williamstown, Kentucky|Williamstown]] and about {{convert|45|mi|km|-1}} from AiG's [[Creation Museum]] in [[Petersburg, Boone County, Kentucky|Petersburg, Kentucky]].<ref name=goodstein2>{{cite news |last=Goodstein |first=Laurie |date=December 5, 2010 |title=In Kentucky, Noah’s Ark Theme Park Is Planned |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2010/12/06/us/06ark.html |work=New York Times |access-date = April 29, 2017 }} </ref>
The city of Williamstown designated a {{convert|1.25|mi|km|adj=on}} radius around the Ark Encounter site as a tax increment financing district, meaning 75 percent of sales and [[property tax]]es collected in the district would return to Ark Encounter for a period of 30 years.<ref name=dinosandall>{{cite web |last=Tucker |first=Lindsay |title=Noah's Ark Rises in Kentucky, Dinosaurs and All |work=Newsweek |date=January 29, 2016 |url=http://www.newsweek.com/2016/01/29/noahs-ark-kentucky-dinosaurs-416653.html |accessdate=May 10, 2016}}</ref> Employees working in the district would also pay a 2 percent employment tax over the same time frame that would go to the Ark Encounter.<ref name=dinosandall /> The Grant County Industrial Development Authority paid Ark Encounter, LLC $195,000 to compensate the corporation for the fact that word of their interest in building the attraction in Grant County had leaked early, causing land prices to double in the area.<ref name=grantcounty>{{cite news |last=Blackford |first=Linda B. |date=August 9, 2011 |title=Noah's Ark theme park to get deep discount on property taxes |url=http://www.kentucky.com/news/local/watchdog/article44119707.html |work=[[Lexington Herald-Leader]] |publisher=[[The McClatchy Company]] |location = [[Lexington, Kentucky]] |access-date = April 29, 2017 }}</ref> Further, the Grant County Fiscal Court discounted the sale price of {{convert|100|acre|ha}} of the site to influence the final selection.<ref name=grantcounty /> Citing the proffered incentives, Ark Encounter, LLC made the Grant County site their final selection and scheduled groundbreaking for August 2011.<ref name="Hansel" /> Plans for additional phases of the park include a model of the [[Tower of Babel]], along with replicas of an ancient walled city and a first-century Middle Eastern village.<ref name=newark>{{cite news |last=Booker |first=Ted |title=Mishawaka firm builds a new Noah's ark – without the flood |newspaper=South Bend Tribune |date=July 6, 2016 |url=http://www.southbendtribune.com/news/local/mishawaka-firm-builds-a-new-noah-s-ark--/article_1d64c44c-eb66-5a13-bb7c-a84ac4dd30c4.html |accessdate=July 8, 2016}}</ref>
===Purchase of site=== Ark Encounter, LLC finalized the purchase of the entire Ark Encounter site in February 2012.<ref name=finalland>{{cite news |author= |date=February 16, 2012 |title=Ky. Noah's Ark attraction gets final piece of land |url=http://www.kypost.com:80/dpp/news/ky-noahs-ark-attaction-gets-final-piece-of-land |work=kypost.com |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120619152139/http://www.kypost.com/dpp/news/ky-noahs-ark-attaction-gets-final-piece-of-land |publisher=[[E. W. Scripps Company]] |agency=Associated Press |location=Cincinnati |archivedate=June 19, 2012 |access-date=April 29, 2017 |deadurl=yes }}</ref> At that time, AiG announced the decision to construct the park in phases, saying it had raised only $5 million<ref name=5million> {{cite web |url=https://answersingenesis.org/ministry-news/ark-encounter/final-piece-of-land-for-full-size-ark-purchased/ |title=Final Piece of Land for Full-size Ark Purchased |website=Answers In Genesis |date=February 16, 2012 |access-date=30 April 2017 |quote= Accordingly, the Ark Encounter will be built in multiple phases ... }}</ref> of the $24 million<ref name=24million> {{cite web |url=https://arkencounter.com/blog/2011/04/29/our-greatest-need/ |title=Our Greatest Need |website=Ark Encounter |date=February 16, 2012 |access-date=30 April 2017 |quote=... $24 million price tag ... }}</ref> needed to begin construction. The first phase included a full-scale model of Noah's Ark and a [[petting zoo]].<ref name=nrb>{{cite news |title=From the Makers of the Creation Museum Comes 'Ark Encounter,' a Noah's Ark Theme Park |publisher=National Religious Broadcasters |date=November 14, 2013 |url=http://nrb.org/news_room/articles/from-the-makers-of-the-creation-museum-comes-ark-encounter-a-noa/ |accessdate=April 21, 2016}}</ref> Plans for five subsequent phases included replicas of an ancient walled city, a first-century Middle Eastern village, and the [[Tower of Babel]]; an [[aviary]]; and a 500-seat special effects theater.<ref name=nrb /><ref name="Largest">{{cite web | last1=Demeropolis | first1=Tom | title=Will the Ark Encounter Rain $4 Billion On the Region's Economy? | url=http://www.bizjournals.com/cincinnati/morning_call/2015/10/will-the-ark-encounter-rain-4-billion-on-the.html | date=October 7, 2015 |work=[[American City Business Journals|Cincinnati Business Courier]] | accessdate=April 27, 2016}}</ref>
[[File:Ken Ham.jpg|thumb|left|upright|[[Ken Ham]], the founder of [[Answers in Genesis]], the group behind Ark Encounter]] In December 2013, the city of Williamstown offered $62 million using [[tax increment financing]] of [[bond (finance)|bonds]] to jump-start construction on the Ark Encounter.<ref name=junk>{{cite news |last=Blackford |first=Linda B. |date=November 27, 2013 |title=City seeks to jump-start stalled Ark Encounter park with $62 million 'junk' bond offering |url=http://www.kentucky.com/news/politics-government/article44455857.html |newspaper=[[Lexington Herald-Leader]] |publisher=[[The McClatchy Company]] |access-date=May 1, 2017 }}</ref> The unrated bonds were backed by the Ark Encounter's projected future revenues, but the city was not liable for repaying them in the event that the revenues didn't materialize.<ref name=junk /> At the time of the offering, Ark Encounter, LLC had raised approximately $14 million toward construction of the park.<ref name=junk /> A group of atheist objectors to the Ark Encounter attempted to disrupt the offering by registering for the sale themselves and conducting a public relations campaign against the bonds.<ref name=whopays>{{cite news |last=Pilcher |first=James |title=Who pays for the new ark? Taxpayers help |newspaper=Cincinnati Enquirer |date=June 28, 2016 |url=http://www.cincinnati.com/story/news/2016/06/23/who-pays-new-ark-taxpayers/85481082/ |accessdate=June 29, 2016}}</ref> In early January 2014, only $26.5 million in bonds had been sold; if at least $55 million in bonds were not sold by February 6, all of the bonds would be automatically redeemed.<ref name=redeemed>{{cite news |last=Chappatta |first=Brian |title=Planned Ark park in Northern Ky. faces collapse without more bond buyers |url=http://www.kentucky.com/news/business/article44465121.html |newspaper=[[Lexington Herald-Leader]] |location=[[Lexington, Kentucky]] |publisher=[[The McClatchy Company]] |agency=[[Bloomberg News]] |date=January 3, 2014 |access-date=May 1, 2017 }}</ref> On February 27, 2014, AiG founder [[Ken Ham]] announced that his February 4 [[Bill Nye–Ken Ham debate|debate on the viability of creationism]] with TV personality [[Bill Nye|Bill Nye "the Science Guy"]] had spurred bond sales, and that the Ark Encounter had raised enough money to begin construction.<ref name=nyedebate>{{cite news |last=Lovan |first=Dylan |title=Noah's ark project spurred by evolution debate |url=http://kcby.com/news/nation-world/noahs-ark-project-spurred-by-evolution-debate-11-13-2015-195954064 |agency=Associated Press |date=February 27, 2014 |access-date=May 1, 2017 }}</ref> AiG officials said the final cost of the park at its opening exceeded $100 million, including $62 million from the Williamstown bond offering and $36 million from individual donations.<ref name=WKYT/> The second phase of the park construction is projected to commence in 2018 or 2019.<ref name="Largest" />
The 2014 Kentucky General Assembly allocated $1.15 million to Grant County for road improvements to accommodate the heavier traffic expected to be generated by the Ark Encounter.<ref name=14roadplan>{{cite news |last1=Brammer |first1=Jack |last2=Cheves |first2=John |title=Lawmakers approve road-building plan, scholarship bill in final hours of legislative session |url=http://www.kentucky.com/news/politics-government/article44484267.html |newspaper=[[Lexington Herald-Leader]] |location=[[Lexington, Kentucky]] |publisher=[[The McClatchy Company]] |date=April 15, 2014 |access-date=May 1, 2017 }}</ref> The Assembly also projected the need for $9.1 million in 2017 to improve the Interstate 75 interchange at Williamstown, but this allocation was beyond the scope of the state's two-year road funding plan.<ref name=14roadplan /> The 2016 General Assembly allocated $10 million to create a new interchange between [[Kentucky Route 36]] (KY 36) and Interstate 75.<ref name=16road>{{cite news |last=Wartman |first=Scott |title=State will pay for revamped exit for Ark Encounter |newspaper=Cincinnati Enquirer |date=April 23, 2016 |url=http://www.cincinnati.com/story/news/politics/2016/04/22/should-kentucky-taxpayers-pay-ark-encounter-road/83360676/ |accessdate=May 11, 2016}}</ref> Until the improvements are completed, AiG is paying for workers to direct traffic on KY 36 near the Ark Encounter.<ref name=16road /> After the initial allocation by the state, AiG invested $500,000 of its own money into improving KY 36; this, and better-than-expected traffic flow, led to the Kentucky Department of Transportation scaling back the proposed improvements, awarding a $3.5 million contract in December 2017.<ref name=17road>{{cite news |title=Road improvements coming to KY 36 near Ark |newspaper=Grant County News and Express |date=December 20, 2017}}</ref> The project is projected to be completed November 2, 2018.<ref name=17road />
In July 2014, with the approved tax incentives set to expire if work on the park had not begun, Ark Encounter withdrew the approved application and filed a new one to receive incentives on the $73 million first phase.<ref name=reapply>{{cite news |last=Loftus |first=Tom |title=Tax incentives sought for Noah's Ark theme park |newspaper=The Messenger |location=Madisonville, Kentucky |date=July 28, 2014}}</ref> The new application required a new feasibility study to be conducted.<ref name=15study>{{cite news |last=Blackford |first=Linda B. |title=Ark park impact in dispute |newspaper=Lexington Herald-Leader |date=January 22, 2015}}</ref> AiG paid for the study, again conducted by Hunden Strategic Partners, which projected a more conservative 400,000 visitors a year, 787 new jobs, and a $40 million economic impact.<ref name=15study /> Shortly after the application was given preliminary approval by the Kentucky Tourism Development Finance Authority, Kentucky [[Speaker of the Kentucky House of Representatives|House Speaker]] [[Greg Stumbo]] said he believed the incentives to be unconstitutional; he added that he expected the state to be sued and lose a costly lawsuit over the issue.<ref name=stumbooppose>{{cite news |last=Brammer |first=Jack |title=Stumbo: State tax incentives for Noah's Ark theme park violate constitution |newspaper=Lexington Herald-Leader |date=July 30, 2014 |url=http://www.kentucky.com/news/politics-government/article44500209.html}}</ref>
===Design and construction=== Cary Summers, who headed [[Herschend Family Entertainment]] from 1992 to 1998, was hired as the lead consultant for the Ark Encounter.<ref name=defendtax /> Patrick Marsh, who helped design exhibits for the Creation Museum and previously designed attractions for [[Universal Studios Florida]], was part of the planning and design team.<ref name=prove>{{cite news |last=Lovan |first=Dylan T. |title=New Noah's Ark in Ky. aims to prove truth of Bible |agency=Associated Press |date=August 17, 2011}}</ref> The Troyer Group, a construction firm in [[Mishawaka, Indiana]], was contracted to oversee construction of the ark, which was constructed by [[Amish]] builders using traditional [[timber framing]] techniques.<ref name=goodstein2 /><ref name=isago>{{cite news |last=Hansel |first=Mark |title=Ark park construction to start this year in Grant |newspaper=The Messenger |location=Madisonville, Kentucky |date=March 11, 2013}}</ref> In total, over 1,000 craftsman were employed in the ark's construction.<ref name=praise>{{cite web |last=Boyd |first=Gordon |title=Ark Encounter opens to praise, protests |publisher=WAVE |date=July 7, 2016 |url=http://www.wave3.com/story/32396682/ark-encounter-opens-to-praise-protests-can-faith-carry-it-financially |accessdate=July 8, 2016}}</ref> As possible, board pulling was used rather than steaming. Steel nails were used to conform with building code regulations.<ref name=wow />
[[File:Ark Encounter lighting.jpg|thumb|right|upright|Lighting at the Ark Encounter is designed to resemble oil lamps.]] While the builders originally planned to hold the ark together with wooden pegs, modern building codes required the builders to use steel fasteners, thus 95 tons of metal plates and bolts were used to connect the wood together.<ref name=meet>{{cite web |last=Ramey |first=Corinne |title=Meet the Creationist Group Building a Life-Size Noah's Ark |publisher=Curbed.com |date=July 8, 2015 |url=http://www.curbed.com/2015/7/8/9943156/answers-in-genesis-ark-encounter |accessdate=June 29, 2016}}</ref> The electric lighting inside was designed to look like [[oil lamp]]s.<ref name=shape /> According to AiG, the Ark Encounter is the largest [[timber frame]] structure in the United States.<ref name=WKYT/>
AiG considered twelve different possible lengths for the biblical [[cubit]], and AiG chose to use a length of {{convert|20.1|in|cm}}; this produced plans for an ark measuring {{convert|510|ft|m|0}} long, {{convert|85|ft|m}} wide, and {{convert|51|ft|m}} high.<ref name=floats>{{cite news |title=Hope floats: Builders of life-size Noah's Ark put faith in $50 million tourism project |newspaper=USA Today |date=November 19, 2012}}</ref> The Ark Encounter consists of approximately {{convert|3300000|bdft|m3}} of wood.<ref name=wow /> The framing of the ark consists mostly of [[Picea engelmannii|Englemann spruce]], while the exterior is made of pine; some of the logs were as long as {{convert|50|ft|m}} long and {{convert|36|in|cm}} in diameter.<ref name=anabaptist>{{cite news |last=Schneider |first=Roger |title=Anabaptist craftsmen use skills to help create ark attraction |newspaper=Goshen News |location=Goshen, Indiana |date=July 3, 2016 |url=http://www.goshennews.com/news/local_news/anabaptist-craftsmen-use-skills-to-help-create-ark-attraction/article_74778491-c112-54e3-a314-c76fbf8caf1c.html |accessdate=July 5, 2016}}</ref>
The park's structures and infrastructure were constructed using environmentally friendly [[Leadership in Energy and Environmental Design]] (LEED) certified methods, including [[geothermal heating]], [[Rainwater harvesting|rainwater capture]], [[active solar|active]] and [[passive solar]] heating.<ref name=leed>{{cite news |last=Kennicott |first=Philip |title=Noah's Ark replica shows conservative Christians are embracing green building |newspaper=Washington Post |date=January 5, 2011 |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2011/01/05/AR2011010505477.html |accessdate=April 21, 2016}}</ref> ''[[The Washington Post]]'' wrote that the decision to use such techniques was exemplary of "a fundamental shift in how religiously conservative Christians think of two basic biblical ideas: dominion and stewardship".<ref name=leed /> Construction crews began clearing timber from the site late in 2012 in order to remove the [[Carya ovata|shagbark hickory]] trees before the endangered [[Indiana bat]]s migrated to the area to nest in them.<ref name=timber>{{cite news |title=Timber! Grant's Ark Park is a go |newspaper=The Messenger |location=Madisonville, Kentucky |date=January 31, 2013}}</ref> Much of the wood used to build the Ark Encounter was sourced from renewable forests or trees infested by beetles.<ref name=mustsee>{{cite web |title=5 Must-See New Architecture Projects For 2016 |publisher=The Urban Developer |date=January 19, 2016 |url=http://www.theurbandeveloper.com/5-must-see-new-architecture-projects-2016/ |accessdate=June 8, 2016}}</ref> During construction, former [[President of the United States|President]] [[Jimmy Carter]] toured the Ark Encounter, accepting an invitation from LeRoy Troyer, president of the Troyer Group.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.wcpo.com/news/state/state-kentucky/former-president-jimmy-carter-visits-planned-christian-theme-park-in-kentucky|title=Former president Jimmy Carter visits planned Ark Encounter theme park in Kentucky|first=Sarah|last=Walsh|date=10 June 2016|work=WCPO Cincinnati|accessdate=13 July 2016}}</ref>
===Opening=== Ark Encounter opened on July 7, 2016, a date (7/7) chosen to correspond with [[Genesis 7]]:7: "And Noah and his sons and his wife and his sons' wives entered the ark to escape the waters of the flood."<ref>[https://www.washingtonpost.com/local/social-issues/a-flagship-for-a-biblical-worldview/2016/07/08/54b50ce2-44a3-11e6-88d0-6adee48be8bc_story.html A flagship for a biblical worldview], ''The Washington Post'', 8 July 2016</ref> AiG also announced that, for the first 40 days and 40 nights of Ark Encounter's operation – an allusion to the inundation period (rain and subterranean hydrological eruptions) of the [[Genesis flood narrative|biblical flood]] – it would extend its hours of operation, offering day and evening tickets.<ref name=40days>{{cite web |last=Law |first=Jeannie |title=Ken Ham's Ark Encounter to Host Millions of Visitors in 40 Days, 40 Nights Opening |work=[[Christian Post]] |date=January 26, 2016 |url=http://www.christianpost.com/news/ken-ham-ark-encounter-host-millions-40-days-40-nights-opening-155856/ |accessdate=May 10, 2016}}</ref> On July 5, AiG held a [[ribbon-cutting ceremony]] for the Ark Encounter, during which members of the media and an estimated 7,000 donors to the project were given an early tour of the ark.<ref name=descend>{{cite news |last=Wartman |first=Scott |title=Thousands descend on rural Ky. town to board ark |newspaper=Cincinnati Enquirer |date=July 5, 2016 |url=http://www.cincinnati.com/story/news/2016/07/05/thousands-descend-rural-ky-town-board-ark/86717690/ |accessdate=July 6, 2016}}</ref> According to the park's publicists, there were 30,000 visitors in its first six days of operation (an average of 5,000 per day).<ref name=repeat>{{cite web |last=Engel |first=Liz |title=Repeat business key to Ark Encounter success: Can attraction keep people coming back? |publisher=[[WCPO]] |date=July 14, 2016 |url=http://www.wcpo.com/news/insider/repeat-business-key-to-ark-success |accessdate=July 14, 2016}}</ref>
[[File:AE 12 stones monument.jpg|thumb|left|upright|A monument erected by the AiG Board of Directors just prior to Ark Encounter's opening, with signage referencing a similar monument from [[Book of Joshua|Joshua]] 4]] Tri-State Freethinkers planned to protest the Ark Encounter's opening with a nearby billboard depicting people drowning around Noah's Ark with the caption "Genocide and Incest Park: Celebrating 2,000 years of myths", but billboard companies [[Lamar Advertising Company]] and Event Advertising and Promotions LLC rejected the design.<ref name=protestboards>{{cite news|title=Atheist Group's Anti-Ark Encounter Billboard Rejected |agency=Associated Press |publisher=ABC News |date=May 11, 2016 |url=http://abcnews.go.com/US/wireStory/atheist-groups-anti-ark-encounter-billboard-rejected-39031306 |accessdate=May 11, 2016 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160512105916/http://abcnews.go.com/US/wireStory/atheist-groups-anti-ark-encounter-billboard-rejected-39031306 |archivedate=May 12, 2016 }}</ref> ''[[The Courier-Journal]]'' reported that approximately 150 opponents of the Ark Encounter gathered near the highway exit to protest the park on its opening day.<ref name=toknow /> [[Eric Hovind]] of Creation Today led a counter-protest during which he offered to pay for any of the ark protesters to tour the ark; the ''Northern Kentucky Tribune'' reported that 21 anti-ark protesters accepted Hovind's offer.<ref name=counter>{{cite news |last=Hansel |first=Mark |title=Ark Encounter protesters and supporters share common ground in an unlikely place |newspaper=The Northern Kentucky Tribune |date=July 9, 2016 |url=http://www.nkytribune.com/2016/07/ark-encounter-protesters-and-supporters-share-common-ground-in-an-unlikely-place/ |accessdate=July 11, 2016}}</ref>
The next day, popular science communicator [[Bill Nye]] accepted Ken Ham's invitation to tour the Ark Encounter,<ref>{{cite web | last1=Contrera | first1=Jessica | title=Bill Nye Visited a Noah's Ark He Doesn't Believe Should Exist | url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/arts-and-entertainment/wp/2016/07/10/bill-nye-visited-a-noahs-ark-he-doesnt-believe-should-exist/ | date=July 10, 2016 | publisher=''[[The Washington Post]]'' | accessdate=July 11, 2016}}</ref> and they had an informal debate as they toured the structure.<ref>{{cite web |last1=Nye|first1=Bill |last2=Ham |first2=Ken |lastauthoramp=yes|title=Nye/Ham: The Second Debate Premiere (video - 117:04)|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=PPLRhVdNp5M |date=13 March 2017 |work=[[YouTube]]}}</ref> Nye stated, "It's all very troubling. You have hundreds of school kids there who have already been indoctrinated and who have been brainwashed. (...) This is about the absolutely wrong idea that the Earth is 6,000 years old that's alarming to me." Earlier in the debate, Ham stated, "My biggest concern is you're teaching generations of young people that they're just animals."<ref>{{cite web |last1=Nye|first1=Bill |last2=Ham |first2=Ken |lastauthoramp=yes |title=Nye/Ham: The Second Debate Premiere (video - 11:43)|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=PPLRhVdNp5M |date=13 March 2017 |website=YouTube}}</ref><ref name=Ortiz /> Footage from Nye's visit was subsequently included in the documentary film ''[[Bill Nye: Science Guy]]'', which was released in 2017.<ref name=nyedoc>{{cite news |last=Addiego |first=Walter |title=The evolution of the science guy |newspaper=The San Francisco Chronicle |date=November 17, 2017}}</ref>
The [[Freedom From Religion Foundation]], an organization that advocates for the [[separation of church and state]], sent letters to over 1,000 public school districts in [[Kentucky]], [[Tennessee]], [[Ohio]], [[Indiana]] and [[West Virginia]] warning them not to organize field trips to the Ark Encounter, arguing that such trips would "expose children to religious proselytizing in violation of the [[Separation of church and state in the United States|constitutional separation of church and state]]."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.kentucky.com/news/local/education/article89061842.html|title=Public schools warned about taking field trips to Noah's Ark park|author=|date=|work=[[kentucky.com]]|accessdate=13 July 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.wcpo.com/news/education/school-groups-warned-against-visiting-noahs-ark-attraction-in-northern-kentucky|title=Noah's Ark, Ark Encounter, Answers in Genesis: Public schools warned against visiting Noah's ark attraction in N. Kentucky|author=[[Associated Press]], WCPO Staff|date=12 July 2016|work=[[WCPO Cincinnati]]|accessdate=13 July 2016}}</ref> Grant County, Kentucky Education Commissioner Stephen Pruitt responded that approval of field trips is a decision of local school boards but that such trips should be directly related to curriculum. He said it is not appropriate for "outside third parties to dictate field trip selections."<ref>{{cite web |URL=http://www.courier-journal.com/story/news/2016/07/12/can-public-schools-take-field-trip-ark-park/87002910/ |last=Lotus |first=Tom |title=Can public schools take field trip to ark park? |publisher=Courier Journal |date=July 13, 2016 |ref=Harv}}</ref> Contending that FFRF was incorrect in their assertion, Ham posted on his blog that he would encourage public school groups to visit the ark by offering admission of $1 per child and no charge for accompanying teachers for the remainder of 2016.<ref name=$1>{{cite news|first=Linda|last=Blackford|url=http://www.kentucky.com/news/local/education/article89557642.html|title=Ark park offers $1 admission to public school kids after field-trip warning|newspaper=[[Lexington Herald Leader]]|date=July 14, 2016}}</ref>
===Subsequent events=== The Tri-State Freethinkers has protested annually at the Ark Encounter on the anniversary of its opening, citing its hiring practices, anti-evolution teachings, and acceptance of state tax incentives as causes for protestors' concerns.<ref name=protests>{{cite news |title=Protesters gather at Ark Encounter on anniversary |newspaper=Grant County News and Express |date=July 11, 2018}}</ref> Local media coverage estimated the size of the 2018 protest to be between 120 and 200 people.<ref name=protests />
In December 2016, for the holiday season, AiG lit the Ark with [[rainbow]] colors, the purpose being to "reclaim the symbol from the [[Rainbow flag (LGBT movement)|gay rights movement]]" and remind viewers of the [[Covenant (biblical)#Noahic covenant|Noahic covenant]].<ref>{{cite web | last1=Wartman | first1=Scott | title=Kentucky Ark Builder Wants to Take Rainbow Back | url=https://www.usatoday.com/story/news/nation/2016/12/23/kentucky-ark-builder-wants-take-rainbow-back/95802416/ | date=December 23, 2016 | publisher=[[USA Today]] | accessdate=January 17, 2017}}</ref> In February 2017, Ken Ham announced AiG would permanently continue the rainbow lighting.<ref>{{cite web | last1=Ham | first1=Ken | title=We're Keeping the Rainbow at the Ark Encounter | url=https://answersingenesis.org/ministry-news/ark-encounter/keeping-rainbow-at-ark-encounter/ | date=February 3, 2017 | publisher=[[Answers in Genesis]] | accessdate=February 5, 2017}}</ref> Permanent lights were installed in July 2017.<ref>{{cite web | last1=Eads | first1=Morgan | title=A Christian Theme Park Claims It Is ‘Taking Back’ the Rainbow From the LGBTQ Community | url=http://www.sacbee.com/news/nation-world/national/article163195713.html | date=July 23, 2017 | publisher=''[[The Sacramento Bee]]'' | accessdate=July 26, 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite web | last1=Puckett | first1=Jeffrey Lee | title=Ark Encounter Thrills Gay Nation With Rainbow Light Display; Twitter Explodes | url=http://www.courier-journal.com/story/news/local/2017/07/20/kentuckys-ark-encounter-thrills-gay-nation-rainbow-light-display/495595001/ | date=July 20, 2017 | publisher=''[[The Courier-Journal]]'' | accessdate=July 26, 2017}}</ref> AiG also plans to open a "Rainbow Garden" near the petting zoo where flowers create a rainbow display.<ref name=2ndyear>{{cite news |title=Ark celebrates 2nd year, eyes expansion |newspaper=Grant County News and Express |date=July 18, 2018}}</ref>
In November 2017, construction began on a 2,500-seat theater on the park's grounds. The theater was originally projected to be completed in time to host the "Equipping Families to Stand" conference, scheduled for July 18, 2018, but construction has been delayed, and the building is now projected to open before the end of 2018.<ref name=2ndyear /><ref name=2017expand>{{cite news |title=Ark Encounter building expansion to host larger events |publisher=WLWT-TV |date=November 14, 2017 |url=http://www.wlwt.com/article/ark-encounter-building-expansion-to-host-larger-events/13629134 |accessdate=November 17, 2017}}</ref> AiG also announced a new children's play area scheduled to open in spring 2019 and an expansion to the petting zoo projected to open by mid-2019.<ref name=2ndyear />
==In the media== [[File:10-21-16-FM2-Tri-x-1600-XTOL1-1-Ark Encounter-DX ERROR (30549949081).jpg|thumb|View of the Ark Encounter from the exterior ground level, October 2016]] On October 22, 2016, the Ark Encounter hosted the premiere of [[Evangelism|evangelist]] [[Ray Comfort]]'s film ''The Atheist Delusion''.<ref>{{cite web | last1=Malado | first1=Jardine | title=Ray Comfort's 'The Atheist Delusion' movie to premiere at Ark Encounter in October | url=http://www.christiantimes.com/article/ray-comforts-the-atheist-delusion-to-premier-at-the-ark-encounter/63153.htm | date=September 22, 2016 | publisher=''The Christian Times'' | accessdate=November 19, 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite web | last1=Zaimov | first1=Stoyan | title=Ken Ham Celebrates 400K Visitors to Ark Encounter, Says He's on Mission With Ray Comfort to Reach Unbelievers | url=http://www.christianpost.com/news/ken-ham-celebrates-400000-visitors-ark-encounter-on-mission-ray-comfort-reach-unbelievers-171133/ | date=October 27, 2016 | publisher=''[[The Christian Post]]'' | accessdate=November 19, 2016}}</ref>
[[Rock and Roll Hall of Fame]]r [[Ozzy Osbourne]] and his son, [[Jack Osbourne|Jack]], visited the Ark Encounter in April 2017 to film an episode of their [[reality television]] series ''[[Ozzy & Jack's World Detour]]''.<ref name=ozzy>{{cite news |last=Kelly |first=Amanda |title=‘Crazy Train’ Ozzy Osbourne makes stop in Grant County |newspaper=Grant County News |date=December 6, 2017 |url=http://www.grantky.com/content/%E2%80%98crazy-train%E2%80%99-ozzy-osbourne-makes-stop-grant-county |accessdate=December 11, 2017}}</ref> The episode, entitled "Kentucky Fried Osbournes", aired on [[A&E (TV channel)|A&E]] on November 29, 2017.<ref name=ozzy />
Ark Encounter was designated the "Sight of the Week" for January 1–7, 2018, by [[Doug Kirby]]'s RoadsideAmerica.com.<ref name=rareview /> The site gave Ark Encounter its highest rating ("The Best"), noting, "the Ark is an attraction that should be visited -- if only because it's unlikely that you'll ever visit anything else like it."<ref name=rareview /> The review characterized the ark as "a very nuts-and-bolts ''American'' Ark, with Noah and his clan in the mold of self-sufficient Pilgrims and innovative pioneers" (emphasis in original).<ref name=rareview />
==Attendance== AiG initially predicted yearly attendance for the attraction of 1.4-2.2 million people. After a year of operation, AiG reported attendance of about 1 million, attributing the lower number to opening in the middle of tourist season.<ref name=enormous>{{cite web | title=Ark Encounter Makes Enormous Impact in First Year | url=https://answersingenesis.org/about/press/2017/07/06/ark-encounter-makes-enormous-impact-in-first-year/ | date=July 6, 2017 | publisher=''Answers in Genesis'' | accessdate=July 9, 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite web | last1=James | first1=Josh | title=Ark Encounter, Protesters Mark One-Year Anniversary | url=http://wuky.org/post/ark-encounter-protesters-mark-one-year-anniversary | date=July 8, 2017 | publisher=[[WUKY]] | accessdate=July 9, 2017}}</ref><ref name=oneyear>{{cite web | last1=Smith | first1=Lawrance | title=1 Year After Opening, Ark Encounter's Attendance and Impact is Growing | url=http://www.wdrb.com/story/35827195/1-year-after-opening-ark-encounters-attendance-and-impact-is-growing | date=July 6, 2017 | publisher=[[WDRB]] | accessdate=July 9, 2017}}</ref>
On February 24, 2017, Executive Director of the Grant County [[Chamber of Commerce]] Jamie Baker stated that the Ark had drawn additional tourism to the area, and that the challenge now was to expand accommodation and other local amenities in order to convert this into economic growth for the county.<ref name=touristflood>{{cite web |last=Smith |first=Lawrence |date=February 24, 2017 |title='Ark Encounter' park bringing a flood of tourists to Grant County, Kentucky |url=http://www.wdrb.com/story/34600699/ark-encounter-park-bringing-a-flood-of-tourists-to-grant-county-kentucky |work=WDRB |quote=The ark did exactly what it said it would do |accessdate=May 1, 2017}}</ref> In March, the Northern Kentucky Convention and Visitors Bureau presented the Ark Encounter with its Star of Tourism award for 2016.<ref name=star>{{cite web |title=NKY Tourism Report: Ark Encounter, Kona Ice Honored |date=March 23, 2017 |publisher=The River City News |url=http://www.rcnky.com/articles/2017/03/23/nky-tourism-report-ark-encounter-kona-ice-honored |accessdate=May 18, 2017}}</ref> Bureau President Eric Summe reported a $23 million increase in visitor spending in nearby [[Boone County, Kentucky|Boone]], [[Kenton County, Kentucky|Kenton]], and [[Campbell County, Kentucky|Campbell]] counties in 2016 over 2015, the year that the region hosted the [[2015 Major League Baseball All-Star Game|Major League Baseball All-Star Game]]; Summe attributed a large part of the increase in spending and hotel occupancy to the opening of the Ark Encounter and an expansion of its sister attraction, AiG's Creation Museum.<ref name=tide>{{cite news |last=Ashwill |first=Vickie |title=Ark Encounter helped tide of Northern Kentucky tourism rise in 2016 |publisher=WCPO |date=May 16, 2017 |url=http://www.wcpo.com/news/insider/ark-encounter-helped-tide-of-northern-kentucky-tourism-rise-in-2016 |accessdate=May 18, 2017}}</ref> In June 2017, Mayor Jim Wells of [[Dry Ridge, Kentucky]] stated that the Ark Encounter had a positive effect on the town, with hotel occupancy rates increasing from 60 to 98 percent since the opening of the attraction.<ref>{{cite web | last1=Weber | first1=Don | title=As One Year Anniversary Approaches, Ark Encounter a Boon for Dry Ridge Hospitality Businesses, Mayor Says | url=http://mycn2.com/politics/as-one-year-anniversary-approaches-ark-encounter-a-boon-for-dry-ridge-hospitaility-businesses-mayor-says | date=June 6, 2017 | publisher=[[Spectrum News]] | accessdate=June 10, 2017}}</ref> In July 2018, [[Nashville]]-based Athena Hospitality Group broke ground on a hotel and restaurant development in Dry Ridge, citing the need for more accommodations for Ark Encounter visitors as the motivation.<ref name=hoteldevelopment>{{cite news |title=Hotel development breaks ground in Dry Ridge |newspaper=Grant County News and Express |date=July 18, 2018}}</ref> The planned development will accommodate three hotels and three restaurants, with the first hotel, an 80-room [[Comfort Suites]] projected to open in the third quarter of 2019.<ref name=hoteldevelopment />
At the end of Ark Encounter's second year, AiG reported an attendance of 1 million visitors for the year.<ref name=1milyr2>{{cite news |last=Knight |first=Cameron |title=Ark Encounter reports 1 million visitors in second year |newspaper=Cincinnati Enquirer |date=July 5, 2018 |url=https://www.cincinnati.com/story/news/2018/07/05/ark-encounter-reports-1-million-visitors-2nd-year/759704002/ |accessdate=July 30, 2018}}</ref> Subsequently, ''[[The Courier-Journal]]'' reported that the Freedom From Religion Foundation had disputed those numbers based upon data obtained through [[Freedom of information in the United States|open records]] requests made to Grant County.<ref name=cj2ndyear>{{cite web |last=Novelly |first=Thomas |title=Not as many people are flooding into Ark Encounter as projected |date=August 2, 2018 |url=https://www.courier-journal.com/story/news/2018/08/02/kentucky-ark-encounter-visitors-sink-lower-than-projections/878239002/ |accessdate=August 2, 2018}}</ref> According to the Foundation, the amount of money collected by the Grant County via its safety assessment fee on ticket sales indicated that only 862,471 people visited the attraction between July 2017 and June 2018.<ref name=cj2ndyear /> In response, AiG spokesman Mark Looy told the paper that this method for calculating attendance was not reliable because it did not include non-paying guests such as children under 5, annual pass holders, and those with lifetime passes, all of whom are admitted to the park for free.<ref name=cj2ndyear /> Because the city of Williamstown based their annual budget on AiG's attendance projections, the city was forced to readjust its budget downward when the number of paying guests fell short of 1 million.<ref>{{cite web |last1=Kelly |first1=Amanda |title=Safety fee assessment projections fall short |url=https://www.grantky.com/content/safety-fee-assessment-projections-fall-short |website=Grant County News |publisher=Grant County News |accessdate=15 November 2018}}</ref>
==Tax incentives controversies== Organizations dedicated to supporting the [[separation of church and state]] were divided on the question of providing tax incentives for the Ark Encounter. [[Barry W. Lynn]] of [[Americans United for Separation of Church and State]] opined that "The government should not be giving tax incentives for religious projects. Religion should be supported by voluntary donations, not the government."<ref name=arkannounce /> Bill Sharp, the staff attorney for the [[American Civil Liberties Union]] of Kentucky, countered that "Courts have found that giving such tax exemptions on a nondiscriminatory basis does not violate the establishment clause, even when the tax exemption goes to a religious purpose."<ref name=arkannounce /> [[Edwin Kagin]] of [[American Atheists]] brought up the difficulty of litigating against the incentives provided by state laws, saying, "The legislation is so drafted that they will give this incentive to any organization that is going to increase tourism in Kentucky, and there's no question whatsoever that this group will."<ref name=prove /> The editorial board of the ''[[Lexington Herald-Leader]]'' wrote that "Ark Encounters [sic] is a private company seeking to make a profit off of a biblical theme. As such, it seems as entitled to apply for incentives from promised profits as any other private, for-profit company in Kentucky."<ref name=lhlcritique>{{cite news |title=Embracing the Ark Incentives mean cheap jobs, poor state image |newspaper=Lexington Herald-Leader |date=December 3, 2010}}</ref> Still, the board was critical of using the incentives to attract low-paying jobs and to facilitate construction of an attraction it characterized as hostile "to science, knowledge and education", which could be off-putting to "the kind of employers that will provide good-paying jobs with a future".<ref name=lhlcritique />
Governor Beshear favored the incentives, stating "The people of Kentucky didn't elect me governor to debate religion. They elected me governor to create jobs," Beshear said, adding, "There's nothing even remotely unconstitutional about a for-profit organization coming in and investing $150 million to create jobs in Kentucky and bring tourism to Kentucky."<ref name=arkannounce /> Responding to an [[Freedom of information in the United States|open records]] request by the ''Lexington Herald-Leader'', Beshear's office later admitted it had not seen the feasibility study cited in its press release, and an administration representative said that the state tourism department would have to conduct its own study in order for the park to be eligible for the incentives.<ref name=feasibility /> The state-commissioned study by Hunden Strategic Partners and paid for by Ark Encounter, LLC, projected that the park would draw nearly 1.4 million visitors a year, but could require the state to widen the Interstate 75 interchange at Williamstown, at an additional cost to the state of about $11 million.<ref name="Hansel">{{cite news |last=Hansel |first=Mark |date=June 11, 2011 |title=Ark park could break ground in August |url=http://www.cincinnati.com/article/20110610/NEWS0103/106110327/Ark-park-could-break-ground-August |work=Cincinnati Enquirer |location=Cincinnati |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141013105508/http://www.cincinnati.com/article/20110610/NEWS0103/106110327/Ark-park-could-break-ground-August |archivedate=October 13, 2014 |access-date=April 29, 2017 |url-access=subscription |deadurl=yes }}</ref><ref name="alford1">{{cite news |last=Alford |first=Roger |date=May 20, 2011 |url=http://www.herald-dispatch.com/news/briefs/x202034968/Noah-s-Ark-theme-park-gets-go-ahead-in-Kentucky |title=Noah's Ark theme park gets go-ahead in Kentucky |newspaper=[[The Herald-Dispatch]] |location=Huntington, WV |agency=Associated Press |accessdate=2014-10-07}}</ref> In an editorial in late December 2010, ''[[The Courier-Journal]]'' questioned the potential cost to the state government of the project, including highway upgrades and the likelihood that increases to [[hospitality industry]] infrastructure would seek further subsidies.<ref>{{cite news |author=<!--Staff writer(s); no by-line.--> |title=A costly modern Ark |url=http://www.courier-journal.com/article/20101229/OPINION01/312290053 |newspaper=[[The Courier-Journal]] |type=Editorial |location=Tysons Corner, VA |publisher=Gannett Company |date=December 28, 2010 |accessdate=2014-10-08}}</ref> In May 2011, the Kentucky Tourism Development Finance Authority voted unanimously to grant incentives of up to $43.1 million to Ark Encounter, LLC. for the project, by then projected to cost $172 million.<ref name="Hansel" /><ref name="alford1" />
In June 2017, Grant County [[County Judge/Executive|Judge Executive]] Stephen P. Wood told the ''Lexington Herald-Leader'' that the tax incentives offered to the Ark Encounter were "a really bad deal for taxpayers".<ref name=trickle>{{cite news |last=Blackford |first=Linda |title=Town expected flood of business after Noah’s Ark opened. So far, it’s a trickle. |publisher=Lexington Herald-Leader |date=June 2, 2017 |url=http://www.kentucky.com/news/state/article154014269.html |accessdate=June 3, 2017}}</ref> Although the valuation of the property within Ark Encounter's tax increment financing district increased from $1.3 million in 2011 to $55 million in 2017, under the terms of its deal with Ark Encounter, the county only retained $63,000 of the $250,000 in property taxes collected within the district, with the rest returning to the park.<ref name=trickle /> School taxes were exempted from the deal, and Grant County Schools saw a 58% increase in property tax revenue from 2016 to 2017.<ref name=trickle />
In April 2017, the city of Williamstown implemented a "safety assessment" of 50 cents per ticket sold at the Ark Encounter, the Williamstown Family Fun Park, and Main Street Gardens to upgrade the city's emergency equipment to sufficiently serve the attractions.<ref name=exemption>{{cite news |title=Williamstown plans to reject Noah’s Ark tax exemption request |newspaper=Lexington Herald-Leader |date=June 29, 2017 |url=http://www.kentucky.com/news/state/article158790694.html |accessdate=July 25, 2017}}</ref> AiG maintained that, as the largest of the three attractions, the assessment placed an undue share of the cost on Ark Encounter.<ref name=willpay>{{cite news |last=Blackford |first=Linda |title=After months of disagreement, Noah’s Ark operators say they will pay safety tax |newspaper=Lexington Herald-Leader |date=July 25, 2017 |url=http://www.kentucky.com/news/state/article163514158.html |accessdate=July 25, 2017}}</ref> After Williamstown officials rejected AiG's request to cap its share of the cost, first at $350,000 and later at $500,000, Ark Encounter LLC sold the main parcel of land for the attraction to its non-profit affiliate, Crosswater Canyon, for $10 and requested an exemption from the fee based on their status as a religious entity.<ref name=willpay /><ref name=requestsexemption>{{cite news |title=Ark Encounter requests safety fee exemption |newspaper=Grant County News |date=June 28, 2017 |url=http://www.grantky.com/content/ark-encounter-requests-safety-fee-exemption |accessdate=July 25, 2017}}</ref> County officials rejected that request.<ref name=willpay />
On July 18, 2017, the state of Kentucky notified Ark Encounter that the sale of the property to Crosswater Canyon put them in breach of their agreement for $18 million in tax incentives.<ref name=transferback>{{cite news |last=Blackford |first=Linda |title=After state suspends tax break, Noah’s Ark park transfers land back to for-profit entity |newspaper=Lexington Herald-Leader |date=July 24, 2017 |url=http://www.kentucky.com/news/state/article163349603.html |accessdate=July 24, 2017}}</ref> Three days later, Crosswater Canyon reversed the sale, transferring the land back to Ark Encounter, LLC for $10.<ref name=transferback /> On July 25, Ark Encounter said they would pay the safety assessment and had been collecting it on tickets sold beginning July 1.<ref name=willpay /> In a public statement, AiG spokesman Mark Looy said, "The filing for an exemption as a religious non-profit (as permitted in the ordinance), was done in an attempt to get the county to change the wording as it currently stands, which would exempt the Ark Encounter. It was not to avoid paying its fair share, as some articles have suggested."<ref name=willpay /> AiG gave no official explanation for the transfer of land to or from Crosswater Canyon, which Williamstown officials had feared could be an attempt to avoid paying property taxes.<ref name=transferback /><ref name=willpay /> The ''[[Grant County News and Express]]'' reported in December 2017 that the safety assessment had generated approximately $213,000 for the city in four months, with less than $500 of that amount being paid by attractions other than Ark Encounter.<ref name=4months>{{cite news |title=Grant County News and Express |newspaper=Grant County News and Express |date=December 13, 2017}}</ref>
In its first year of operation, Ark Encounter generated over $2.28 million in sales taxes for the state of Kentucky, a figure which excluded the period during which the attraction was owned by Crosswater Canyon.<ref name=year1rebate>{{cite news |last=Blackford |first=Linda |title=Noah's Ark theme park getting $1.8 million state tax rebate after first year |newspaper=Lexington Herald-Leader |date=September 7, 2017 |url=http://www.kentucky.com/news/state/article171736687.html |accessdate=September 7, 2017}}</ref> Ark Encounter received a rebate of $1.8 million of the collected taxes, the maximum amount allowed for the year under terms of its agreement with the state.<ref name=year1rebate />
==Hiring policies controversy== {{multiple image <!-- Layout parameters --> | align = right | direction = horizontal | background color = <!-- box background --> | total_width = 400 | caption_align = | header_background = | header_align = | header = | image1 = AE days of creation display.jpg | alt1 = | link1 = | thumbtime1 = | caption1 = An Ark Encounter display describing the [[Genesis creation narrative]]. | image2 = AE Grand Canyon signage.jpg | alt2 = | link2 = | thumbtime2 = | caption2 = An Ark Encounter display promoting a relatively rapid formation of the [[Grand Canyon]] as a result of the [[Genesis flood narrative|Genesis flood]]. | footer_background = | footer_align = left | footer = Ark Encounter employees must sign a statement that they agree with tenets of [[young Earth creationism]] such as the [[Genesis creation narrative]] and [[flood geology]]. }}
[[Americans United for the Separation of Church and State]] petitioned the Kentucky Tourism Development Finance Authority in August 2014 to withdraw its preliminary approval of tax incentives for the Ark Encounter because of AiG's hiring practices, which required all applicants to profess Christianity and sign a statement of faith attesting to their beliefs in [[young Earth creationism]] and that homosexuality is sinful among other requirements.<ref name=aupetition>{{cite news |title=Group opposes tax incentives for Noah's Ark park |agency=Associated Press State Wire |date=August 23, 2014|url=http://www.wkyt.com/home/headlines/Group-opposes-tax-incentives-for-Noahs-Ark-park-272415671.html|accessdate=11 June 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |last=Costello |first=Carol |title=Kentucky's magnificent, controversial ark |publisher=CNN |date=June 21, 2016 |url=http://edition.cnn.com/2016/06/21/opinions/kentucky-ark-costello/index.html |accessdate=July 15, 2016}}</ref> Zovath countered that the Ark Encounter's hiring policies had not been written yet and that the hiring policies of AiG should not be a factor because Ark Encounter, LLC was the entity receiving the incentives.<ref name=aupetition /> In response to Americans United's petition, a spokesman for the Kentucky Tourism, Arts and Heritage Cabinet said, "As a condition of any incentive program, all projects must follow all state and federal laws, including all laws related to hiring."<ref name=aupetition /> Following Americans United's petition, the ''[[Lexington Herald-Leader]]'' editorial board also called for the incentives to be rescinded.<ref name=lhlrescind>{{cite news | author = <!--Editorial; no byline--> | date = August 27, 2014 | title = No more state aid for Ark Park | url = http://www.kentucky.com/opinion/editorials/article44505702.html | work = Lexington Herald-Leader | location = Lexington, Kentucky | access-date = April 29, 2017 }}</ref>
In October, Kentucky Tourism Arts and Heritage Cabinet Secretary Bob Stewart wrote to AiG requesting "express written assurance from Ark Encounter that it will not discriminate in any way on the basis of religion in hiring for the project".<ref name=limbo>{{cite news |last=Blackford |first=Linda B. |title=Ark tax incentives in limbo over hiring |newspaper=Lexington Herald-Leader |date=October 8, 2014}}</ref> Citing the [[Supreme Court of the United States|Supreme Court]]'s decision in ''[[Burwell v. Hobby Lobby Stores, Inc.|Burwell v. Hobby Lobby]]'', which found that individuals had the right "to run their businesses as for-profit corporations in the manner required by their religious beliefs", AiG refused, insisting that Ark Encounter had the right to "include religion as a criteria in its future hiring decisions".<ref name=denies>{{cite news |last=Blackford |first=Linda B. |title=State denies $18M in incentive |newspaper=Lexington Herald-Leader |date=December 11, 2014}}</ref><ref name=nobreaks>{{cite news |last=Lovan |first=Dylan |title=Kentucky: No tax breaks for Noah's Ark project |agency=Associated Press State Wire |date=December 10, 2014|url=https://www.cincinnati.com/story/news/2014/12/10/kentucky-tax-breaks-noahs-ark-project/20214733/|accessdate=11 June 2018}}</ref> In December 2014, Stewart announced that the incentives would be withdrawn, because the facility was to be used for religious indoctrination instead of as a tourist attraction, and because of complaints of hiring discrimination.<ref>{{Cite news|title=Tax Breaks Are Withdrawn For Park That's Site of a New Noah's Ark|agency=Associated Press|work=The New York Times|date=December 11, 2014|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2014/12/11/us/politics/kentucky-no-tax-break-for-site-of-a-new-noahs-ark.html|accessdate=11 June 2018}}</ref> During the Christmas holidays, AiG conducted a billboard public relations campaign in support of the project in several metropolitan areas in Kentucky and a digital billboard in [[New York City]]'s [[Times Square]].<ref name=happening>{{cite news |last=Baker-Nantz |first=Jaime |title=Ark isn't sunk; 'it's happening' |newspaper=The Messenger |location=Madisonville, Kentucky |date=December 18, 2014}}</ref>
Ark Encounter LLC, filed a religious discrimination lawsuit against the state in February 2015.<ref name=tosue>{{cite web |title=AiG to file discrimination suit against Kentucky |publisher=WHAS |date=February 3, 2015 |url=http://legacy.whas11.com/story/news/local/2015/02/03/aig-ark-encounter-kentucky-federal-lawsuit-state-officials/22807647/ |accessdate=May 10, 2016}}</ref> Freedom Guard chief counsel Mike Johnson represented AiG for free in the suit, which alleged the state of Kentucky violated Ark Encounter's [[First Amendment to the United States Constitution|First Amendment]] free speech rights by denying the incentives.<ref name=tosue /> AiG officials maintained that the incentives, potentially worth $18 million, were not necessary to complete construction of the ark, but they would accelerate the timeline for constructing additional phases of the Ark Encounter.<ref name=withorwithout>{{cite news |last=Loftus |first=Tom |title=Noah's Ark park moves ahead with or without state help |newspaper=The Messenger |location=Madisonville, Kentucky |date=June 16, 2015}}</ref> After [[Conservatism in the United States|conservative]] [[Matt Bevin]] [[Kentucky gubernatorial election, 2015|was elected]] to succeed Steve Beshear as governor in November 2015, [[Kentucky Senate]] Majority Leader [[Damon Thayer]] said he would encourage the new governor's administration to restore the tax incentives and render AiG's lawsuit moot, but Ham insisted that AiG preferred to have the matter adjudicated to set a legal precedent.<ref name=thayer>{{cite news |last=Williams |first=Chris |title=Ky. lawmaker supports Ark Encounter tax breaks |publisher=WHAS |date=November 12, 2015|url=https://www.whas11.com/article/news/local/ky-lawmaker-supports-ark-encounter-tax-breaks/417-29711845|accessdate=11 June 2018}}</ref>
On January 25, 2016, [[United States federal judge|Federal Judge]] [[Gregory F. Van Tatenhove]] of the [[United States District Court for the Eastern District of Kentucky]] ruled in favor of AiG in the case of ''Ark Encounter LLC et al. vs. Bob Stewart et al.'', ordering the state to commence processing the application for the tax rebate incentives that would become available once the Ark Encounter opened.<ref>{{cite news | last1=Lovan | first1=Dylan | title=Ark Encounter Builder Wins Legal Battle Over Tax Incentive | url=http://www.wcpo.com/news/local-news/grant-county/ark-encounter-builder-wins-legal-battle-over-tax-incentives | date=January 25, 2016 | work=WPCO.com | accessdate=February 1, 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite news | last1=Caproni | first1=Erin | title=Judge Rules on Ark Encounter Incentives | url=http://www.bizjournals.com/cincinnati/morning_call/2016/01/judge-rules-on-ark-encounter-incentives.html | date=January 26, 2016 | work=[[American City Business Journals#Newspapers|Cincinnati Business Courier]] | accessdate=February 1, 2016}}</ref> Bevin announced that the state would not appeal Van Tatenhove's decision, and later replaced four of the nine members on the Tourism Development Finance Authority.<ref name=dinosandall /><ref name=16award>{{cite news |last=Blackford |first=Linda B. |title=Noah's Ark park – State awards $18 million tax break to theme park |newspaper=Lexington Herald-Leader |date=April 27, 2016|url=http://www.kentucky.com/news/state/article73971147.html|accessdate=11 June 2018}}</ref> Ark Encounter began advertising to fill 300 to 400 jobs in the park in April 2016; applicants were required to sign a statement of faith before being hired.<ref name=hiring>{{cite news |last=Lovan |first=Dylan |title=Noah's Ark job float your boat? Then you must be Christian |agency=Associated Press State Wire |date=April 14, 2016|url=https://apnews.com/f80fd80eddea41b2a00266ca91b36f92|accessdate=11 June 2018}}</ref> Two weeks later, the Tourism Development Finance Authority approved the incentives.<ref name=loftus/>
==See also== * [[Flood myth]] and [[List of flood myths]] * [[Noah's Ark replicas and derivatives]] * [[Religious cosmology]]

{{Infobox legislation |short_title = Asiatic Land Tenure and Indian Representation Act, 1946 |legislature = |image = Coat of Arms of South Africa (1932-2000).svg |imagesize = |imagealt = |caption = |long_title = Act to impose restrictions with regard to the acquisition and occupation of fixed property in the Province of Natal; to amend the law relating to the ownership and occupation of fixed property in the Province of Transvaal; to make special provision for the representation in Parliament of Indians in the Provinces of Natal and Transvaal, and for the representation in the Provincial Council of Natal, of Indians in that province; and to provide for other incidental matters. |citation = Act No. 28 of 1946 |territorial_extent = |enacted_by = [[Parliament of South Africa]] |date_enacted = |date_passed = |enacted_by2 = |date_enacted2 = |date_passed2 = |date_assented = |royal_assent = 3 June 1946 |date_signed = |date_commenced = 6 June 1946 |date_of_expiry = |date_repealed = 12 October 1948 (representation)
30 June 1991 (land tenure) |administered_by = [[Minister of the Interior (South Africa)|Minister of the Interior]] |bill = |bill_citation = |bill_date = |introduced_by = |1st_reading = |2nd_reading = |3rd_reading = |conf_committee_passed = |bill2 = |bill_citation2 = |bill_date2 = |introduced_by2 = |1st_reading2 = |2nd_reading2 = |3rd_reading2 = |conf_committee_passed2 = |date_conf_committee = |white_paper = |committee_report = |amendments = |repeals = [[Asiatic Laws Amendment Act, 1948]] (representation)
[[Abolition of Racially Based Land Measures Act, 1991]] (land tenure) |related_legislation = |summary = |keywords = |status = repealed }} The '''Asiatic Land Tenure and Indian Representation Act, 1946''' (Act No. 28 of 1946; subsequently renamed the '''Asiatic Land Tenure Act, 1946''', and also known as the "Ghetto Act") of South Africa sought to confine Asian ownership and occupation of land to certain clearly defined areas of towns. The Act also prohibited Asians from owning or occupying property without a permit when such property had not been owned or occupied by Asians before 1946. Furthermore, it granted Indians in the [[Transvaal Province|Transvaal]] and [[Natal Province|Natal]] the right to elect Whites to represent them in [[Parliament of South Africa|Parliament]] and for Natal Indians to represent themselves in the [[Natal Provincial Council]]. The Act deprived the Asian South Africans of communal representation and took away their fundamental and elementary right of land ownership and occupation. It is called and regarded universally by Indian people as the "Ghetto Act". The act struck at the heart of Indian commercial and economic life. Not only did it intend to reduce the levels of Indian trade and reduce progress in the acquisition of fixed property, it also is thought to have reduced the opportunities of the masses of the Indian people to earn a decent living and ultimately condemn them to existence in increasingly over-crowded slums and locations. Thus on 31 March 1948, it is thought that about 6,000 Indians marched in protest to the Act in [[Durban]], South Africa. The sections of the act granting representation in Parliament and the provincial council were repealed by the [[Asiatic Laws Amendment Act, 1948]]. The rest of the act was repealed by the [[Abolition of Racially Based Land Measures Act, 1991]]. ==See also== * [[:Category:Apartheid laws in South Africa]] * [[Apartheid in South Africa]] ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== * [http://africanhistory.about.com/library/bl/blsalaws.htm African History: Apartheid Legislation in South Africa] *[http://www.nelsonmandela.org/omalley/index.php/site/q/03lv01538/04lv01646/05lv01813.htm Brief description of the Asiatic Land Tenure and Representation Act 1946 No. 28] {{Apartheid legislation navbox}} [[Category:Apartheid laws in South Africa]] [[Category:1946 in South African law]] {{Apartheid-sa-law-stub}} {{Statute-stub}}

The '''Border Security Force''' ('''BSF''') is the primary [[Border control#Border security|border defence organisation]] of India. It is one of the five [[Central Armed Police Forces]] of the Union of India, it was raised in the wake of the 1965 War on 1 December 1965, "for ensuring the security of the borders of [[India]] and for matters connected there with".<ref name="BSF Act">{{cite web|last1=Government Of India |title=THE BORDER SECURITY FORCE ACT, 1968No. 47 of 1968 |url=http://bsf.nic.in/doc/bsfActRules.pdf |publisher=MINISTRY OF LAW (Legislative Department ) |accessdate=8 September 2014 |pages=1–2 |language=English, Hindi |date=2 September 1968 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141017063459/http://bsf.nic.in/doc/bsfActRules.pdf |archivedate=17 October 2014 |df=dmy }}</ref><ref name="Border Security Force">{{cite web|last1=Border Security Force|title=ROLE OF THE BSF|url=http://bsf.nic.in/en/introduction1.html|website=Border Security Force, [[Ministry of Home Affairs (India)|Ministry of Home Affairs]]|publisher=Border Security Force|accessdate=8 September 2014|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140908224637/http://bsf.nic.in/en/introduction1.html|archivedate=8 September 2014|df=dmy-all}}</ref> It is a [[Central Armed Police Force]] charged with guarding India's land border during peacetime and preventing transnational crime. It is a Union Government Agency under the administrative control of Ministry of Home Affairs. The BSF has its own cadre of officers but its head, designated as a [[Director-General]] (DG), since its raising has been an officer from the [[Indian Police Service]]. It is an Armed Force of the Union of India tasked with various assignments from time to time.<ref name="Border Security Force"/> The BSF has grown exponentially from a few battalions in 1965, to 186 [[battalion]]s with a sanctioned strength of 257,363 personnel including an expanding air wing, [[Border Security Force (Water Wing)|marine wing]], artillery regiments, and commando units.<ref name="air wing, BSF">{{cite web|url=http://bsf.nic.in/en/air-wing.html|title=BSF Air Wing|last=|first=|date=|website=Border Security Force|publisher=Border Security Force|accessdate=8 September 2014|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140820142102/http://www.bsf.nic.in/en/air-wing.html|archivedate=20 August 2014|df=dmy-all}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://mha.nic.in/sites/upload_files/mha/files/EnglAnnualReport2016-17_17042017.pdf|title=MHA Report 2016-2017|last=|first=|date=|website=|access-date=|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170808200948/http://mha.nic.in/sites/upload_files/mha/files/EnglAnnualReport2016-17_17042017.pdf|archivedate=8 August 2017|df=dmy-all}}</ref> It currently stands as the world's largest border guarding force. BSF has been termed as the ''First Line of Defence'' of Indian Territories.<ref>{{cite news|title=BSF is first Wall of Defence of India, says Home Minister Rajnath Singh at 13th Investiture Ceremony|url=http://news.biharprabha.com/2015/05/union-home-minister-rajnath-singh-at-13th-bsf-investiture-ceremony/|accessdate=22 May 2015|agency=ANI|publisher=news.biharprabha.com|date=22 May 2015|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150522155318/http://news.biharprabha.com/2015/05/union-home-minister-rajnath-singh-at-13th-bsf-investiture-ceremony/|archivedate=22 May 2015|df=dmy-all}}</ref>

== History == [[File: Indian BSF Soldier.jpg|thumb|A soldier of India's Border Security Force in one of the ceremonial uniforms.]] [[File: BSF MEN HELPING IN MEDIACAL CAMP.jpg|thumb|BSF soldiers contributing and supporting at a Medical Camp, India.]]
From [[Indian independence movement|independence]] in 1947 to 1965, the protection of India's international boundaries was the responsibility of local police belonging to each border state, with little inter-state coordination. BSF was created as a Central government-controlled security force to guard all of India's borders, thus bringing greater cohesion in border security. BSF is charged with guarding India's land border during peacetime and preventing transnational crime. It is a Union Government Agency under the administrative control of the Ministry of Home Affairs. It is one of many law enforcement agencies of India.<ref name="bsf.nic.in1">{{cite web|url=http://bsf.nic.in/en/introduction.html|title=Border Security Force|website=bsf.nic.in}}</ref> It currently stands as the world's largest border guarding force.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://economictimes.indiatimes.com/news/defence/raising-day-six-facts-you-should-know-about-the-exceptional-border-security-force-of-india/largest-force/slideshow/61877729.cms|title=Raising Day: Six facts you should know about the exceptional Border Security Force Of India - Guarding India since 1965|website=The Economic Times}}</ref>

== Formation == During the [[Indo-Pakistani War of 1965]], the border management system was in the hands of the individual state police forces, and these proved incapable of properly dealing with border threats. Following these episodes, the government created the Border Security Force as a unified central agency with the specific mandate of guarding India's international boundaries. [[K F Rustamji]], from the Indian Police Service, was the first Director General of BSF. Till 1965 India’s borders with Pakistan were manned by the State Armed Police Battalion. Pakistan attacked Sardar Post, Chhar Bet, and Beria Bet on 9 April 1965 in Kutch. This exposed the inadequacy of the State Armed Police to cope with armed aggression due to which the Government of India felt the need for a specialized centrally controlled Border Security Force, which would be armed and trained to man the International Border with Pakistan. As a result of the recommendations of the Committee of Secretaries, the Border Security Force came into existence on 1 Dec 1965 with K F Rustamji as its first Director General.<ref name="bsf.nic.in1"/>
The BSF's capabilities were used in the [[Indo-Pakistani War of 1971]] against [[Pakistani Armed Forces|Pakistani forces]] in areas where the [[Military of India|Regular Forces]] were thinly spread; BSF troops took part in several operations including the famous [[Battle of Longewala]]. In fact, for BSF the war on eastern front had started well before the war actually broke out in Dec '71. BSF had trained, supported and formed part of "[[Mukti Bahini]]" and had entered erstwhile East Pakistan before the actual hostilities broke out. BSF had played a very important role in [[Bangladesh Liberation War|Liberation of Bangladesh]] which [[Indira Gandhi]] and [[Sheikh Mujibur Rehman]] had also acknowledged.
The BSF, long considered a male bastion, has now deployed its first batch of women personnel at the border to carry out regular frisking of women as well as other duties performed by their male counterparts, including guarding the border. Over 100 women have been deployed on the highly volatile [[Indo-Pakistani border|Indo-Pak border]], while around 60 will be deployed on the [[India–Bangladesh border|Indo-Bangla border]]. In total, 595 women constables will be deployed on the border in different phases.
